question:

Question Text: What is the value of \( A \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 3 \)
Answer B Text: \( 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( 6 \)
Answer D Text: \( 9 \)

question:
Question Text: Which digits will change when I subtract \( 20 \) from \( 10,000 \) ?
Answer A Text: All the digits will change
Answer B Text: Only the tens will change
Answer C Text: The tens and the ones will change
Answer D Text: All the digits apart from the ones will change
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'hello'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Zara, would you like some help with this question?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how are you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm good thanks, how are you?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im stuck on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's have a look together."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, we're thinking about place value in this question.  10,000 is ten thousand.  And 20 is twenty or two tens."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Let's think about an easier number first...it might help. What is 100-20?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '80'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, so which digits changed when you did that sum?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'the tens and then there were no hundreds left'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, great!  So the hundreds and the tens changed. So, do you think this would be the same for 10,000 or if you're not sure we could look at 1000 first?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So, what is 1000-80?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '200'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm still just taking tens away...in fact I meant to say 1000-20, so have a go at 1000-20."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '800'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "1000-200=800, but we're doing 1000-20, have another go?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh that would be 980'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great!  Well done! and then getting to the question above, what is 10,000-20?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9800'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Nearly...you've taken away 200, but you only need to take away 20."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh that is 9980'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great!  You can probably see a pattern emerging.  But now, you know the answer to your question above, which answer is it?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is the answer d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes!  Great work, Zara!  I'll leave you to enter your answer now if you're happy with this?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': ':-) Well done!'}]

question:
Question Text: Martha has \( \frac{2}{3} \) of a whole cake in the fridge. Edward eats \( \frac{1}{3} \) of this piece. What fraction of the whole cake has Edward eaten? Choose the number sentence that would solve the word problem.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{3}+\frac{2}{3} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{2}{3} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{2}{3} \div \frac{1}{3} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3} \)

Answer D Text: \( (16-6+4) \div 2 \)

Answer A Text: \( 7+4 \times 5 \)
Answer B Text: \( 19+16 \div 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 10+44 \div 2 \)
Answer D Text: \( 60-3 \times 11 \)

question:
Question Text: A greengrocer makes a stack of \( 45 \) melons and \( 60 \) grapefruits. He wants to make a mini version of the stack but only has \( 24 \) grapefruits. How many melons does he need to makes the stacks similar?
Answer A Text: \( 18 \)
Answer B Text: \( 9 \)
Answer C Text: \( 20 \)
Answer D Text: \( 24 \)

question:
Question Text: A greengrocer makes a stack of \( 45 \) melons and \( 60 \) grapefruits. He wants to make a mini version of the stack but only has \( 24 \) grapefruits. How many melons does he need to makes the stacks similar?
Answer A Text: \( 18 \)

Answer A Image: A straight line graph showing Canadian dollars on the y axis up to 10 and Pounds on the x axis up to 20. With a straight line, with a positive gradient, from the origin

Answer C Image: A straight line graph showing Canadian dollars on the y axis up to 20 and Pounds on the x axis up to 10 with a straight horizontal line from 20 on the y axis.
Answer D Image: A straight line graph showing Canadian dollars on the y axis up to 20 and Pounds on the x axis up to 10. Straight line with a positive gradient drawn from approx 5 on the y axis

question:
Question Text: Add brackets to this calculation so that the answer is \( 5 \) \[ 22-10+8 \div 4 \]
Answer A Text: \( 22-(10+8) \div 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( (22-10)+8 \div 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( (22-10+8) \div 4 \)
Answer D Text: \( 22-10+(8 \div 4) \)

question:
Question Text: There are \( 72 \) conkers in a bag. Kai takes \( \frac{1}{3} \) of them. Sophia takes \( \frac{4}{6} \) How many do they have in total?
Answer A Text: \( 72 \)
Answer B Text: \( 0 \)
Answer C Text: \( 24 \)
Answer D Text: \( 48 \)

question:
Question Text: Amira has \( 6 m \) of rope. She cuts it into fifths. How long is each piece?
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{l}1 \mathrm{~m} \text { and } \\ 200 \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{c}1 \mathrm{~m} \text { and } 2 \\ \mathrm{~mm}\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{c}1 \mathrm{~m} \text { and } 2 \\ \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( 1 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 20 \) \( \mathrm{cm} \)

question:
Question Text: \( x y=715000 \) to \( 3 \) significant figures
Question Text: \( x=20 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
Question Text: Which of these is the minimum value of \( y \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 47700 \)
Answer B Text: \( 35750 \)
Answer C Text: \( 28580 \)
Answer D Text: \( 28620 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again Leilani!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "hi. I don't understand what to do"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'There are a few steps here. So, to find the minimum value of y, we first need to work out the minimum value of xy.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '35750?#'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "xy = 715000 to 3 sf. So what's the lowest it could have been before it was rounded?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '714500?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, that works for me. So, the smallest we're going to get to is 714500 by doing xy. If we want to find the smallest possible value of y, then we need x to be as BIG as possible. What's the biggest x could be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '19'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's smaller than 20"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '24'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Nearly, but like the last question we worked on together, the upper bound will be the first number that would round up to 30. so that anything even slightly smaller than it would round down.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'to 20. Yes, spot on. So, we have xy = 714500 (its smallest possible) and x = 25 (biggest possible).'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so is it C'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You beat me to it! Yes, 714500/25 gets you C. Would you like to ask any more questions? Or shall I pass you back to Eedi?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes please'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Will do!'}]

So what's the lowest it could have been before it was rounded?", 'student': '714500?'}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': "Yes, that works for me. So, the smallest we're going to get to is 714500 by doing xy. If we want to find the smallest possible value of y, then we need x to be as BIG as possible. What's the biggest x could be?", 'student': '19'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': "That's smaller than 20", 'student': '24'}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': 'Nearly, but like the last question we worked on together, the upper bound will be the first number that would round up to 30. so that anything even slightly smaller than it would round down.', 'student': '25'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': 'to 20. Yes, spot on. So, we have xy = 714500 (its smallest possible) and x = 25 (biggest possible).', 'student': 'so is it C'}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': 'You beat me to it! Yes, 714500/25 gets you C. question:
Question Text: \( Â£ 13000 \) is invested at \( 5 \% \) compound interest per annum. What is the total interest earned after \( 4 \) years?
Answer A Text: \( Â£ 2600 \)
Answer B Text: \( Â£ 2801.58 \)
Answer C Text: \( Â£ 15600 \)
Answer D Text: \( Â£ 15801.58 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hey! How can I help? ğŸ˜ƒ'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hey. i dont know the answer to this please can you help me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Of course. Let's call the initial investment 100%. if we have 5% interest what % do we have?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '105%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. What is 105% as a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1.05'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. Now we want to multiply the 13000 by 1.05 to the power of the number of years. Do you have a calculator?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yeppe'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '13000 x 1.05^4 ='}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15801.58125'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. So that is the total we now have. The question asks for just the interest'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How would we work out what the interest is?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'idk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'The interest is the difference between what we invested and what we now have'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'kk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '15801.58 - 13000'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2801.58'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! question:
Question Text: A house increases in value by \( 12 \% \) each year. After how many full years will the value of the house have at least doubled in price?
Answer A Text: \( 6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 9 \)
Answer C Text: \( 7 \)
Answer D Text: \( 8 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Amelia!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont understand the house question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's have a look. So, the percentage we have is 0.12. To calculate an increase by 12%, what will the multiplier be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, 12%, but we would be multiplying by 1.12 to get the new value each year. Does this make sense?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'where did you get 1.12 from'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It's multiplying by 112%, 100% is the original value. and then we're adding 12% as well"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohh okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And we want the house price to at least double. So what percentage are we looking for (double the original value)?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '112?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite....we're multiplying by 112% each year, but. we need to keep doing that until the value doubles...so until we get to 200%"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh right'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, so let's try this... CAn you calculate 1.12 x 1.12?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1.2544. but why do you do 1.12 x 1.12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Because we want to know how many times we need to increase by 12% (multiply by 1.12) until the value has doubled...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh right okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "And we want the price to double... it will have doubled when we reach 200%... which is when we get to 2, because we're working with decimals"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh i get it now'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, we need to multiply by 1.12 again... and keep going until you get an answer of 2 or bigger... and remember how many times you've multiplied by 1.12 becuase that will be the answer... So, far you've done 1.12 x 1.12 = 1.2544. so this is for 2 years. Then multiply again by 1.12 to get the percentage increase after 3 years"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so do i keep doing 1.12 x 1.12 till i get to 2 or more'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay i get it now thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done! Bye for now ğŸ‘‹'}]

question:
Question Text: A house increases in value by \( 12 \% \) each year. After how many full years will the value of the house have at least doubled in price?
Answer A Text: \( 6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 9 \)
Answer C Text: \( 7 \)
Answer D Text: \( 8 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hey! How can I help? ğŸ˜ƒ'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Hi, I don't know how to work out this question"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "With a question like this we can pick a starting value to work with. Let's say the house was Â£100 (it doesn't matter that it's a really low value). If Â£100 increased by 12% how much would it be worth?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '112 pounds'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. For the house to have at least doubled in price, what do we need the price to get to?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '200 pounds'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great. If 112 increases by 12% what would we get to?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '125.44?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. No. 6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '6 times gets us to 197.38'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so 7'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, 7 gets us to 221.07. Are you confident using decimal multipliers for compound interest?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'A bit'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'what would be the decimal multiplier for increasung by 12%? *increasing'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.12. 1/12. 1.12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '1.12 is correct, well done'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Typos ğŸ˜…'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'another way we could have answered this is to try the years with the decimal multiplier. we could have tried 100 x 1.12^6 for answer A. 100 x 1.12^9 for answer B'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh I get it now! wow, I overthink this question a lot'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'and seen which one gave us the answer over and closest to 200. Are you happy to head back to the lesson? ğŸ™‚'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yeah! ğŸ˜„'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. Bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: A jacket is reduced in a sale by \( 10 \% \). A customer has a loyalty card for a further \( 5 \% \) off the price.  What is the overall percentage decrease in the price of the jacket?
Answer A Text: \( 15 \% \)
Answer B Text: \( 4.5 \% \)
Answer C Text: \( 0.5 \% \)
Answer D Text: \( 14.5 \% \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i am not sure how to answer this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Let me take a look. Ok, let's say it started at Â£100 (we could choose any number but 100 is nice when working with percentages). It is first reduced by 10%. What price would it now be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '90'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So the jacket is now Â£90. What happens next?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'the customer has a loyalty card for 5%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great! So we need to take off 5% of Â£90'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Â£85.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! Now we need to work out the overall percentage reduction. The jacket started at Â£100 and eded at Â£85.5. So what percentage did it decrease by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'not quite. That would take me down from Â£100 to Â£85'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh 14.5%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'That\'s it! It\'s one that tricks everyone. Because the 5% wasn\'t 5% of the original price, it was 5% of the discounted price, so slightly less. Always best with these ones to choose Â£100 as your starting value and do it in stages. I hope that helped"'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'it did thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': ':)'}]

question:
Question Text: Lina turns clockwise from facing \( \mathrm{NW} \) to facing \( \mathrm{S} \)  How many degrees has Lina turned?
Question Image: A image of a compass.
Answer A Text: \( 225^{\degree} \)
Answer B Text: \( 315^{\degree} \)
Answer C Text: \( 135^{\degree} \)
Answer D Text: \( 180^{\degree} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Zuri, would you like help with this question?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Yes please. I don't really understand how many degrees it takes from NW to N and how much it would take overall"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem. How many degrees in a full turn?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '360'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, well done! And how many degrees between W and N?  Which is also a quarter turn. Hi Zuri! Do you know how many degrees there are between W and N? It's a right angle, so how many degrees is that?  If you're not sure, let me know."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "90 degrees. But it's not an option here"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, great, no that's not the final answer, we're just working it out. We first need to get from NW to N.  NW is half way in between W and N, so how many degrees will that be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '180 plus 90. 270'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're nearly there, you've got the 180 part right - because that's how far it is from N to S. But we need to add on NW to N, which is half of the turn from W to N, so half of 90 degrees.  Let me know if that makes sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "So that's 315 degrees"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Can you tell me what numbers you're adding togther?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '45 + 270'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, from NW to N is 45 degrees and then from N to S is 180 degrees.  This is the full journey from facing NW to turning anti-clockwise to S.  SO it would be 180+45.  Is there a part of this that you are unsure of? Sorry!  That should say CLOCKWISE!  I've written it wrong above!  Clockwise from NW to S."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm sure of everything now. Thanks for helping me. Again"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem at all! :-)  Keep up the good work, I'll leave you to it."}]

- An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.']}, 'turn 5': {'correct': False, 'kcs': ['Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. dialogue: [{'turn': 1, 'teacher': 'Hi Zuri, would you like help with this question?', 'student': "Yes please. I don't really understand how many degrees it takes from NW to N and how much it would take overall"}, {'turn': 2, 'teacher': 'No problem. How many degrees in a full turn?', 'student': '360'}, {'turn': 3, 'teacher': "Yes, well done! And how many degrees between W and N?  Which is also a quarter turn. Hi Zuri! Do you know how many degrees there are between W and N? It's a right angle, so how many degrees is that?  If you're not sure, let me know.", 'student': "90 degrees. But it's not an option here"}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': "Ok, great, no that's not the final answer, we're just working it out. We first need to get from NW to N.  NW is half way in between W and N, so how many degrees will that be?", 'student': '180 plus 90. 270'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': "You're nearly there, you've got the 180 part right - because that's how far it is from N to S. But we need to add on NW to N, which is half of the turn from W to N, so half of 90 degrees.  Let me know if that makes sense?", 'student': "So that's 315 degrees"}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': "Can you tell me what numbers you're adding togther?", 'student': '45 + 270'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': "Ok, from NW to N is 45 degrees and then from N to S is 180 degrees.  This is the full journey from facing NW to turning anti-clockwise to S.  SO it would be 180+45.  Is there a part of this that you are unsure of? Sorry!  That should say CLOCKWISE!  I've written it wrong above!  Clockwise from NW to S.", 'student': "I'm sure of everything now. Thanks for helping me. Again"}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': "No problem at all! :-)  Keep up the good work, I'll leave you to it.", 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline Polygon & \begin{tabular}{c}  Number of \\ sides \end{tabular} & \begin{tabular}{c}  Sum of interior \\ angles \end{tabular} \\ \hline Quadrilateral & \( 4 \) & \( 360^{\circ} \) \\ \hline Pentagon & \( 5 \) & \( 540^{\circ} \) \\ \hline Hexagon & \( 6 \) & \( 720^{\circ} \) \\ \hline Heptagon & \( 7 \) & \( ? \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Question Text: What is the missing angle?
Answer A Text: \( 810^{\circ} \)
Answer B Text: \( 1080^{\circ} \)
Answer C Text: \( 1260^{\circ} \)
Answer D Text: \( 900^{\circ} \)

question:
Question Text: These are both regular polygons. Calculate the unknown angle, \( x \).
Question Image: A hexagon and a square are joined together, sharing one side which is the same length. 'x' is the angle on the outside of where these shapes join.
Answer A Text: \( 210^{\circ} \)
Answer B Text: \( 180^{\circ} \)
Answer C Text: \( 225^{\circ} \)
Answer D Text: \( 150^{\circ} \)

question:
Question Text: \(120 \) blue sheep and \( 90 \) yellow sheep are tested for a disease. The pie charts show the results for each type of sheep.  From the tested sheep, are there more blue or yellow with the disease? By how many?
Question Image: diseased \[ 90^{\circ} \]
Question Image: A pie chart showing a major sector coloured white showing 220 degrees and a minor sector coloured yellow containing the word diseased.
Answer A Text: More blue, by \( 30 \)
Answer B Text: More blue, by \( 55 \)
Answer C Text: More blue, by \( 35 \)
Answer D Text: More yellow, by \( 25 \)

question:

Question Text: Four numbers have a mean of \( 6 \). \( \begin{array}{cccc} 4 &5 & ? & 9 \end{array} \) Find the value of the missing number.
Answer A Text: \( 7 \)
Answer B Text: \( 24 \)
Answer C Text: \( 18 \)
Answer D Text: \( 6 \)

question:
Question Text: This graph shows how many people visited a museum.
Question Image: Chart showing number of viewers against year
Question Text: How many more people visited in \( 2014 \) than in \( 2013 ? \)
Answer A Text: \( 75,000 \)
Answer B Text: \( 350,000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 25,000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 750,000 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hi Jordan. I'll just take a look at the question for you. The y-axis is titled "Amount in millilitres" and the scale is from 0 to 1500 in steps of 250. The following points are plotted and joined together: (9am, 250), (10am, 375), (11am, 500), (12pm, 750), (1pm, 750), (2pm, 500), (3pm, 625), (4pm, 750), (5pm, 1000), (6pm, 750), (7pm, 500).

Answer A Text: \( 3000 \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer B Text: \( 6750 \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer C Text: \( 4875 \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer D Text: \( 250 \mathrm{ml} \)

question:
Question Text: How far away from home was Natalie at 12:15?
Question Image: A line graph with title "A graph to show the distance Natalie travels from her home on her daily run."  The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0800 to 1300 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 1300. The y-axis is titled "Distance from home (Km)" and the scale is from 0 to 8 in steps of 1km. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0800, 0), (0830, 2), (0900, 3.5),(1000, 6), (1030, 7), (1100, 7.5),(1230, 7.5),(1300, 4.5), (1330, 0).
Answer A Text: \( 0 \mathrm{~km} \)
Answer B Text: \( 7.5 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer C Text: \( 750 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer D Text: \( 7500 \mathrm{~m} \)

question:
Question Text: Expand and simplify: \[ 4(2 x+1)-(5 x-9) \]
Answer A Text: \( 3 x-5 \)
Answer B Text: \( 3 x+13 \)
Answer C Text: \( 13 x-5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 13 x+13 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I need help i don't understand"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem, let's look at it together! It looks like you are confident with expanding one bracket, is that true?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, so in this question we have to expand each bracket on its own, just like you have been doing, then simplify by putting terms together. What did you get when you expanded the first bracket? 4(2x+1) ='}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '8x+4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect, and then -(5x-9) = ? Remember a - sign on its own is like -1'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-20x-36'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Just looking at this bracket on its own, multiplying the terms in the bracket by -1'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Huh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So forget the other bracket with the 4 for now, you have a separate bracket to expand here. You are expanding the bracket -(5x-9)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-5x-9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Almost, what happens with -1 x -9? question:
Question Text: Factorise the following expression fully \[ 24 x+72 \]
Answer A Text: \( 2(12 x+36) \)
Answer B Text: \( 24(x+3) \)
Answer C Text: \( 6(4 x+12) \)
Answer D Text: \( 4(6 x+18) \)

question:
Question Text: What is the median number of siblings?
Question Image: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline Siblings(s) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\ \hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\ \hline \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) \\ \hline \( 2 \) & \( 9 \) \\ \hline \( 3 \) & \( 10 \) \\ \hline \( 4 \) & \( 7 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Answer A Text: \( 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 3 \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Leila!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi iam dont know hat to do'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you know what "median" means?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes. well kind of'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! It's the middle number when all the data is written out in order from smallest to largest. It can seem trickier in a table, but it's the same idea. So, just to show you how it works... The table tells us that 4 people have 0 siblings, do you agree?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘. So, if this was a list of data it would look like this.... 0,0,0,0,. and then 3 people said they have 1 sibling, so our data list is now... 0,0,0,0,1,1,1..... Do you agree?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! Now, I don't have to write out all of the data like this...but I'm doing it because when we first learn about medians, we always start by looking at a list of data. If I did keep writing out all the data, how many numbers would I end up writing in total?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '33'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect!  Well done! Ok, so if I wrote out 33 numbers, what is the position of the middle number?   e.g. is it the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th etc?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '16.5. beetween 16 17'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Nearly...well done, you've got the right idea. question:
Question Text: What is the median number of siblings?
Question Image: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline Siblings(s) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\ \hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\ \hline \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) \\ \hline \( 2 \) & \( 9 \) \\ \hline \( 3 \) & \( 10 \) \\ \hline \( 4 \) & \( 7 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Answer A Text: \( 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 3 \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 \)

question:
Question Text: The following table shows the weight of Easter Eggs:
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \multicolumn{5}{|c|}{ Weight of Easter Eggs (g) } & Frequency & Mid Point & Mid-Point x Freq & Cumulative Frequency \\ \hline \( 100 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 200 \) & \( 18 \) & \( 150 \) & \( 2700 \) & \( 18 \) \\ \hline \( 200 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 300 \) & \( 16 \) & \( 250 \) & \( 4000 \) & \( 34 \) \\ \hline \( 300 \) & \( \leq \) & w & \( < \) & \( 500 \) & \( 10 \) & \( 400 \) & \( 4000 \) & \( 44 \) \\ \hline \( 500 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 800 \) & \( 12 \) & \( 650 \) & \( 7800 \) & \( 56 \) \\ \hline \( 800 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 1000 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 900 \) & \( 3600 \) & \( 60 \) \\ \hline \multicolumn{5}{|c|}{ TOTALS } & \( 60 \) & & \( 22100 \) & \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Question Text: What does the circled number represent?
Answer A Text: The total number of eggs that weigh between \( 300 \mathrm{~g} \) and \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \)
Answer B Text: The exact total weight of the \( 10 \) eggs in the \( 300 \) to \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \) category
Answer C Text: The average weight of the Easter Eggs between \( 300 \mathrm{~g} \) and \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \)
Answer D Text: Our best estimate at the total weight of the \( 10 \) eggs in the \( 300 \) to \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \) category

question:
Question Text: You are given data on the lifespan of two different batches of lightbulb, manufactured at the same company. By looking at the data, decide which of the statements below is true. Batch A Mean: \( 1100 \) hours Range: \( 50 \) hours Batch B Mean: \( 800 \) hours Range: \( 400 \) hours
Answer A Text: â€œOn average, batch B's lightbulbs last a shorter length of time and are more consistent"
Answer B Text: â€œOn average, batch A's lightbulbs last a shorter length of time, but are more consistent"
Answer C Text: â€œOn average, batch A's lightbulbs last a longer length of time, and are less consistent"
Answer D Text: "The lifespans for batch A's lightbulbs are more similar to each other than batch B's"

question:
Question Text: A running club has \( 40 \) members.  \( 25 \) of the members take part in road races. \( 12 \) of the members take part in fell races. \( 8 \) of the members do not run in road or fell races.  \( \mathbf{R} \) represents those runners who run in Road races. F represents those runners who run in Fell races.  What is the probability a member takes place in a Road Race but not a Fell Race?
Question Image: Shows an empty venn diagram with each circle labelled R and then F.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{20}{40} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{25}{40} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{13}{40} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{5}{40} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm not sure"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's start with putting some numbers on that diagram....so... The running club has 40 members."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And it gives us facts about how many members in total?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes I know that but the wording of the question is weird. It confuses me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok...well I'll try and break it down into stages so we can go through it together. So, how far have you got with the question? I can start at the beginning, or part way through if you've already done some of it?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25 ran road races 12 ran fell races 5 both'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great...5 both.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "8 just didn't run any"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'perfect. So, we need to know how many do road races only.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Nearly...but that 25 will include the ones who did road AND fell'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Wait I just realised.is it 20,the answer. It changed my words'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great - you ARE a maths genie â­ï¸. Great! Well done! I'll leave you to enter your answer. ğŸ™‚"}]

question:
Question Text: The probability of picking a green ball is \( \frac{1}{5} \) Where is this value on the probability scale?
Question Image: A diagram showing a probability scale with 10 segments. The scale starts at 0.0, has 0.5 marked after 5 segments, and 1.0 marked at the end, after 10 segments. A is marked after 2 segments, B after 4, C after 5 and D after 7.
Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How are you getting on with this question? ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi i dont understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We can do it together then! So do you know what 1/5 is as a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.1. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's 1/10... and 1/5 = 2/10. So 2/10 as a decimal?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So 1/5 = 0.2. Now can you see where 0.2 would be located?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'before 0.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great, so that means it's A or B. Is 0.2 closer to 0, or to 0.5?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So which one shall we go for?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'a'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'There we go! Well done! so either try and remember hat 1/5 = 0.2'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thx'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Or change 1/5 into 2/10 by doubling both numbers, to jog your memory it's 0.2. You're very welcome, bye Javier!"}]

Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D

Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{c}1 \mathrm{~cm} \text { by } \\ 36 \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 9 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{c}6 \mathrm{~cm} \text { by } \\ 6 \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( A, B \) and \( C \)

Answer B Text: \( 750,000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 425,000 \)

Question Text: How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 20 \) and \( 50 \) seconds?

Answer B Text: \( 85 \)
Answer C Text: \( 30 \)
Answer D Text: \( 55 \)

question:
Question Text: How many grams are there in \( 1 \) tonne?

Answer B Text: \( 1000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 2000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1000000 \)

question:
Question Text: A right-angled tringle has sides a, b, and \( c \) as shown.  Choose the formula for finding side a.
Question Image: Right-angled triangle with height a, base b and hypotenuse c.
Answer A Text: \( a=c-b \)
Answer B Text: \( a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2} \)
Answer C Text: \( a^{2}=b^{2}-c^{2} \)
Answer D Text: \( a^{2}=c^{2}-b^{2} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Leo how are you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi sylvia, im not sure on his question. this'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm just reading it."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "wait it's B i think"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'do you know about Pythagoras Theorem? sorry not B but close'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes, its a squared + b squared = c squared'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'lovely! question:
Question Image: Positive coordinate grid, going up to 8 in both the x and y directions, with the point A labelled at (3,6)
Question Text: Point \( A \) is reflected in the line \( y=3 \). What are the coordinates of the new point?
Answer A Text: \( (2,3) \)
Answer B Text: \( (4,6) \)
Answer C Text: \( (2,0) \)
Answer D Text: \( (0,2) \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Isabella. What does the line y = 3 look like?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'a line going through the 3 in the y coordinate. going up'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It doesn't go up - it's a horizontal line through 3 on the y-axis"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so across?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It connects all the points where the y-coordinate is 3. Question Image: A bar diagram showing 45 split into five nines.
Question Text: Which of the following calculations is not represented by the diagram above?
Answer A Text: \( 5=45 \div 9 \)
Answer B Text: \( 5 \times 9=45 \)
Answer C Text: \( 45=9 \times 5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 5 \div 45=9 \)

question:
Question Text: Which statement about the temperatures \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is true?
Answer A Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)  colder than  \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer B Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 12^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)  colder than  \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer C Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) hotter than \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer D Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 12^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)  hotter than \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

question:
Question Image: Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4
Question Text: Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
Answer A Text: \( 4+5=-1 \)
Answer B Text: \( -1+5=4 \)
Answer C Text: \( -1+4=5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1+4=5 \)

Question Text: Which of the following calculations would correctly work out the difference between the temperature at \( 1 \mathrm{pm} \) on Thursday and the temperature at \( 1 \) am on Wednesday?

Answer B Text: \( 7-(-4) \)
Answer C Text: \( 7+(-4) \)
Answer D Text: \( 7-4 \)

question:
Question Text: \( (-5) \div \frac{1}{2}=(-5) \times \square \)
Question Text: What belongs in the box?
Answer A Text: \( 0.5 \)
Answer B Text: \( -2.5 \)
Answer C Text: \( 2 \)
Answer D Text: Not possible

Question Text: Which calculation is equal to \( -20 \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 2 \times(-2)-(-4) \times 4 \)

Answer C Text: \( (-5)^{2}+5 \)
Answer D Text: \( (-42) \div(-2)+1 \)

question:
Question Text: Statement 1: \( \quad p \times(-q)=(-p) \times q \) Statement 2: \( \quad-(q)^{2}=q^{2} \) What can you say about the above statements, where \( p \) and \( q \) represent different numbers?
Answer A Text: Only statement \( 1 \) is true
Answer B Text: Only statement \( 2 \) is true
Answer C Text: Both statements are true
Answer D Text: Both statements are false

question:
Question Text: "Square numbers have an odd number of factors"  Is this statement...
Answer A Text: always true
Answer B Text: sometimes true
Answer C Text: never true
Answer D Text: Impossible to say
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Valentina. How can I help you today with factors and multiples. Lets try an example together. Can you think of a square number?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '36'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Brilliant, lets think of the factors of 36. So remember factors are numbers that divide evenly into the number without leaving a remainder. What numbers divide evenly into 36?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1 36             3 36            4 9        6 6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Amazing, we have 1 x 36, 4 x 9, 6 x 6, 3 x 12 and there is another factor pair? Think if its even what number definitely goes into 36?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 18'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fantastic Valentina :). So if we were to right the factors for 36 we would say  1,2,3,4,6,9,12,18 and 36. How many factors is this'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Is this an odd number or even?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'odd'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent, all square numbers have an odd number of factors, can you think why Valentina?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so would it be A always true?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes :). Does this help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes, thank you very much:)'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem. I will return you to the lesson and just ask if you need any help'}]

question:
Question Text: Which expression should replace the star in the addition pyramid?
Question Image: A diagram showing 3 rows of boxes. the bottom row has 3 boxes, containing 4a, 3b and 3a+b from left to right. The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. The left one is empty, the right one contains 3a+4b. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, containing a star.
Answer A Text: \( 6 a+5 b \)
Answer B Text: \( 7 a+7 b \)
Answer C Text: \( 14 a b \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 a+8 b \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there!  How can I help you? ğŸ˜„'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'can you please help me on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course!  Let\'s have a look! Alright, it looks like we are looking for the value of the star here. Let\'s have a look at the block below it, the one that reads "3a +4b". Do you know why they wrote 3a + 4b in that block?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so you can simplify that'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, they collected like terms to simplify it! Looking at collecting like terms, what would be in the blank block? Above the "4a" and the "3b"?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '7a+7b? 14ab?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Close, but not quite...  We can only combine or collect the terms together if they have the same variable.  Do 4a and 3b have the same variable?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Right, they do not. So we cannot combine or collect them, so we have to leave them separately. So we would write that 4a and 3b combined are 4a + 3b. You can think of it as apples and oranges.  We cannot combine their numbers unless they are the same fruit. How does that sound?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'great'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Awesome!  If it is confusing, please let me know.  The video above is also really helpful in explaining it. So we have 4a + 3b and we need to combine it with 3a + 4b. What would they be if we collected like terms of 4a + 3b and 3a + 4b together?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how do i click the answer'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Would you like me to send you back so you can complete it?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes please'}]

Pattern 1 is 6 dots: they are arranged as a rectangle, 4 dots high and 1 dot wide and then 2 more dots in a row to the right of the bottom dot. Pattern 4 is 18 dots arranged as a rectangle, 4 dots high and 4 dots wide and then 2 more dots in a row to the right of the bottom dots.
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Lisa
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Lisa
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: Jack and Emma are arguing about parallelograms. Jack says a square is a type of parallelogram. Emma says a rhombus is a type of parallelogram. Who is correct?
Question Image: Parallelogram with equal, parallel sides marked
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again Lulu!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello ğŸ˜€'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What are we tackling now?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I am not very sure how to answer the question above'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Can you tell me what makes a parallelogram a parallelogram? Its properties? If you can't see the question any more, scroll up and click on it and it will pin it for you."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Parallel  sides'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Keep going...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm not usre what else. *sure"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well, opposite sides have to be parallel. AND the same length. So the two widths are the same lengths, and the two slanted heights are the same length.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Right...'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What are the properties of a square?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Sorry I'm not really catching up. Equal sides"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, a square must have all four sides the same - what about the angles?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'The angles are also the same'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes. Now, does a square have opposite sides the same length?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And are opposite sides parallel to each other in a square?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yeah!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "They are! So it IS a type of parallelogram because it fits the properties of a parallelogram. All squares are parallelograms, but not all parallelograms are squares (because some parallelograms don't have angles of 90 degree, for example)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh! Thanks!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can you do a similar sort of reasoning for the second part? Work out whether a rhombus fits the properties of a parallelogram?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So they are both right?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'They are! Feel happy with it or would you like to ask me anything else?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Happy'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'OK, shall I pass you back?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks for taking the time to teach me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're welcome!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes please :D'}]

question:

Answer A Text: \( 0.5 \)

Answer C Text: \( 0.4 \)

question:
Question Text: Points \( \mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q} \) and \( \mathrm{R} \) are equally spaced along the line segment.  The coordinates of \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{R} \) are marked on the diagram.  What are the coordinates of \( Q \) ?
Question Image: Graph with 4 quadrants, showing points P(-3, 6), R(1, -2) and Q (an unknown coordinate in quadrant 2)
Answer A Text: \( (-1,3) \)
Answer B Text: \( (-2,4) \)
Answer C Text: \( (-1,2) \)
Answer D Text: \( (-2,2) \)

question:
Question Text: The line segment is one side of a square.  Which of the following coordinates could be a vertex of the square?
Question Image: coordinate graph showing -4 to +4 in x and y direction with linear graph y = x -1 drawn for x values from -2 to +2
Answer A Text: \( (0,-1) \)
Answer B Text: \( (-2,4) \)
Answer C Text: \( (2,-7) \)
Answer D Text: \( (-4,2) \)

Answer B Text: Q

question:
Question Text: Sam and Mike are arguing about how to calculate the perimeter of the symmetrical shape shown.
Question Image: Two, identical parallelograms stuck together to form the point of an arrow. The height of the whole shape is 10cm. The slant length of the parallelograms is 6cm and the base is 4cm.
Question Text: Sam says you can do: \( 2 \times 4+2 \times 10 \)
Question Text: Mike says you can do: \( 2 \times(2 \times 6+4) \)
Question Text: Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Sam
Answer B Text: Only Mike
Answer C Text: Both Sam and Mike
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! how can I help you today? oh, a perimeter queston!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "i don't know how to do this question because i thought you just added all the sides"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, to find the perimeter you do just add all the sides. and a good way to do these sort of questions is to do it your own way and then check if either person in the question got the same answer as you. so, if you add up the length of all the sides remember to add even the ones that have no numbers written on them. let me knw what you get for the perimeter'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '28'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "oh I got a different answer, so let's look at it together for a moment. how many of the sides will be 6cm? it says the shape is symmetrical. (sorry if I take a while to reply to your messages, I am helping a couple of people at the same time)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, I agree there are 4 sides each 6cm. and then how many sides are 4cm?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes I agree! so we have 4 lots of 6 and then also 2 lots of 4. work out what that comes to altogether'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '30'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'check again. 4x6=? and 2x4=?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '32'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ys, I agree! Well done! now, check the queston again. what does sam's calculation come to if we work it out?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'mike is right'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Sam's answer comes to 28 so is def wrong. did you work out Mike's answer? sorry my laptop might have frozen there!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes it is 32'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "oh that's the same as we got, so yes indeed Mikel is right! well done!! are you happy for me to leave and you can answer the question?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes, thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ğŸ‘‹you are welcome, it's been lovely working with you. Enjoy the rest of the lesson!"}]

Answer A Image: Isosceles triangle with base 5, other sides 3.9, and perpendicular height 3
Answer B Image: Right angled triangle with base 5 and height 6
Answer C Image: Scalene triangle with base 3, perpendicular height 5, and slanted height 10
Answer D Text: They all have the same area

question:
Question Text: Ben and Sophie are arguing about powers. Ben says \( 2^{6}=4^{3} \) Sophie says \( 2^{6}=8^{2} \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Ben
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Ben and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi David :) How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont know how it isnt just ben'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok let's take a look. Shall we start by working out 2^6? 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '=12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite. This doesn't mean 2 x 6. It means 6 copies of 2 all multiplied together. Like this: 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '64'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great! And can you work out 4^3?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '36'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite. 4^3 means 4 x 4 x 4'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '32. 64'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "4 x 4 is 16. Then when we multiply by 4 again we get 64. That's great! So Ben is correct. Now let's check Sophie. We know that 2^6 is 64. What is 8^2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '64'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'fab! Can you tell me how you got 64?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '8x8=64'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great work! So remember the little raised number is called a 'power' and it tells us how many copies of the number we need to multiply together. Are you feeling more confident with this?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's great ğŸŒŸ I'll hand you back to the session"}]

Question Text: Leo and Lily are arguing about powers. \( m \) and \( n \) are integers  Leo says there is no value of \( m \) that means \( 2^{m} \) ends in \( 0 \). Lily says there is no value of \( n \) that means \( 5^{n} \) ends in \( 0 \). Who is correct?

Answer B Text: Only Lily
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Lily
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: \( a \) and \( b \) are different numbers.  Which of the following numbers could this be the complete factor tree for?
Question Image: Factor tree with a question mark at the top, and two lines down to two circles. The letters a and b are each in one of the circles.
Answer A Text: \( 45 \)
Answer B Text: \( 47 \)
Answer C Text: \( 49 \)
Answer D Text: \( 51 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi JOrdan, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Hi, I don't understand factor trees"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Let me give you a minute to have a look at the video first then I can explain any parts you don;t get. As it is a bit difficult to explain via chat'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I did but I don;t understand the questions as ter. as there are no nu,bers to start with'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Oh I see the pinned question now!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Let's go through it together"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think its 49 as 7 x 7. is that right?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes good start. It only has 2 factors but it says a and b are different numbers'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "ok. so i said 45 originally but that was wrong. i'm confused"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '45 has factors 9 and 5. But then 9 is not a prime number so can be broken down to 3x3. We need a number with only 2 factors but unique numbers. So it cannot be 45 and 49'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What about 47?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What factors does it have?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1. 47'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes it is a prime number so that looks right. and then 51 is a bit trickier it would be 17 x 3. Does that help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "OK i don';t understand what the answer is. 49 or 51"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '51 would be the answer'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'soory 47 or 51'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'As both 17 and 3 are prime numbers so the tree would not continue'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'OK think I get it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Excellent! I'll hand you back to select your answer now!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Bye for nowğŸ‘‹'}]

question:
Question Text: Jack and Emma are still arguing about the number expressed as \( 3^{4} \times 5^{2} \times 7^{2} \) Jack says \( 10 \) is a factor of the number. Emma says \( 75 \) is a factor of the number. Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Sophie!  How can I be of help? ğŸ˜„'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi is there a way of doing the previous question faster?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Let me have a look at it...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How did you do it Sophie?  Did you make a factor tree?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I worked out 3x3x3x3 then i did 5x5 and then 7x7 and multiplied all of them together but it took me quite a long time.'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'I see.  So I think there is a way that you could check this and it would be shorter.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay what is it?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So you see that factors we have, with 3â´, 5Â² and 7Â².  That tells us we multiply three 4's, two 5's and two 7's.  Does that make sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes, but could you do four threes?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Sorry, you are right, four three's."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "What we can do is try to make up the factors that Jack and Emma have from these 3's, 5's and 7's."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, can you multiply to 75 using 3's, 5's and 7's?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Right!  We can do 5 x 5 x 3 = 75.  That means 75 is a factor. Can you multiply to get 10 using 3's, 5's and 7's?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no. Sorry but ive got to go now'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You cannot, so it is NOT a factor.  You can do that with any number to see if it is a factor.  Would you like to practice one?  Or do you feel confident to be sent back? Okay, nice job!  I'll send you back."}]

question:
Question Text: Leo and Lila are arguing equivalent fractions. Leo says \( \frac{9}{15}=\frac{12}{20} \) Lila says \( \frac{9}{15}=\frac{15}{21} \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Leo
Answer B Text: Only Lila
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Lila
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Darius :). How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is the answer A? by any chance'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can you explain why to me?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no not really.'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's go through it then"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can you simplify the first fraction they have? The 9/15?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yeah sure. 3/5 ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'perfect! Now Leo had 12/20. would that also simplify to 3/5?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What if I divided the top and bottom by 4?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "super, so because they both simplify to the same fraction they are equal so Leo is right. Answer A Text: Only Liam
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Liam and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: What is \( \frac{7}{8} \) as a decimal?
Answer A Text: \( 0.8 \)
Answer B Text: \( 0.7 \)
Answer C Text: \( 0.78 \)
Answer D Text: None of these
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can i help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I need help on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What would 1/8 be as a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.8?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I see what you're thinking but not quite. what is 1/2 as a decimal?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Perfect. Because 1/2 just means 1 divided by 2. So if we want 1/8 we're going to start with 1/2 and half it again. so 0.5 divided by 2 is?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I don't know ğŸ¤”"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What would 1/4 be as a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1.5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite. So 1/4 would be 0.25 as a decimal or 25% as a percentage. 1/2 = 0.5 = 50%. 1/4=0.25 = 25%. So to find 1/8 we're just going to half 0.25. or you can do 25% divide by 2/"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite, lets break it down. What is half of 20%?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '10'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And half of 5%?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If I had Â£5 and I gave you half of it. How much would it be?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I don't know?"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It would be 2.5%. So 1/8 = 12.5% What would that be as a decimal'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '12.5. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You need to divide by 100 to change a percentage to a decimal? So 12.5 divide by 100'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.125'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. Now we want 7/8. So we need to do 0.125 x 7'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.875'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great job. Which answer are you going to pick then?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'D?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yeah I think so'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great job sticking at it there!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Byeâœ‹'}]

question:
Question Text: \( \frac{2}{7} \times 3=3 \div K \times L \)
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{l}K=7 \\ L=2\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{l}K=2 \\ L=7\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{l}K=7 \\ L=7\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: Not possible

So like 1/2,one half, means 1 Ã· 2'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2/7 times 3 = 6/7. Then I donâ€™t get the bit after'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yep great, so on the left we have 6 Ã· 7, to write it another way. And we need to make the right side equal the same thing'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yea but I donâ€™t know what to do'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So what two things do we need to do to 3 to make it equal 6 Ã· 7? Multiply it by something, and divide it by something. 3 x __ = 6?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep, so if we multiply 3 by 2, and divide it by 7, we'll get 6/7. Does that make sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great :) It's ok that they are switched around to divide by 7 and then times by 2, the result is the same. Just make sure you get them the right way round in the answer, so you are not multiplying by 7 instead! Good to go?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So is the answer b'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Careful, which one is saying Ã·7?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh so it a'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep :) didn't want you to get caught out! Ok to go on now?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab, bye!'}]

question:
Question Image: 'A rectangle' = 1
Question Text: Which of the following calculations could this diagram represent?
Question Image: Four rectangles, cut into three boxes each. Each box is labelled 1/3.
Answer A Text: \( 12 \times \frac{1}{3}=4 \frac{1}{3} \)
Answer B Text: \( 12 \times \frac{1}{3}=36 \)
Answer C Text: \( 4 \times \frac{1}{3}=12 \)
Answer D Text: \( 12 \times \frac{1}{3}=4 \)

B is one of them, which is th other? sorry for my typos!!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'its okay dont worry'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'thanks'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'B and A?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "yes, and D as well. question:

question:
Question Text: Alex has two fraction cards. \( \frac{5}{8} \quad \square\) The product of the cards is \( \frac{1}{6} \) What is the other card?
Answer A Text: \( \frac{19}{24} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{5}{48} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{15}{4} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{4}{15} \)

question:
Question Text: Clayton has two fraction cards. \( \frac{3}{7} \quad \square\) The product of the cards is \( \frac{2}{5} \) What is the other card?
Answer A Text: \( \frac{29}{35} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{14}{15} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{1}{35} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{6}{35} \)

Do you have any ide whay? idea why*"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Nope'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So we are dividing because it is the opposite of multiplying. Now we want to solve for the "?", which means we need to get the "?" by itself. To do that, we need to remove the 3/7, which means we need to do the opposite operation on it. question:
Question Text: Work out: \( 1-\frac{3}{8} \)

Answer B Text: \( \frac{5}{8} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{2}{8} \)

It would help if we rewrote the '1' as a fraction. What denominator would we like it to have?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '8'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes! What fraction would be equal to 1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'c'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No, 2/8 isn't equal to 1. Don't worry about the answers in the question just yet, we need to rewrite 1 as a fraction first."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/8'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If I offered you 1 pizza or 1/8 of a pizza, would you feel those two options were equal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "OK, so 1 and 1/8 are not equal to each other. If we cut a pizza into eighths, how many slices would we have? (It doesn't have to be a pizza, it's just what I think of!)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '8'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes! So 1 whole pizza is the same as 8/8. Which changes the question from 1 - 3/8 to 8/8 - 3/8. Any idea then?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'b'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, that gets you answer B. Well done! Would you like me to hand you back to the lesson now?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes pls'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'OK, keep persevering1'}]

So let's times both numbers in the fraction 1/4 by 3 iin order to change it to an equivalent fraction with 12 as the denominator. what do we get when we times 1/4 top and bottom by 3? you ok Joshua? Can you tell me 1x3 and 4x3?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3/12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great!! question:
Question Text: Work out:
Question Text: \( \frac{5}{7}-\frac{1}{4} \)
Question Text: Give your answer in the simplest form.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{27}{28} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{4}{3} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{13}{28} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{7} \)

What could it be in this case?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '28?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, that works. What's the next step?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im not sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Let's look at the first fraction, 5/7. Want me to hand you back to the lesson?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes please, thanks for the help'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're welcome!"}]

turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Aylin, Would you like some help with this question?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi Chloe I was just stuck on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'OK, no problem.  So, to add or subtract fractions, we need them all to have the same denominator.  Do you know how to tackle this?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'You would make all the denominations the same which is 20?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great!  Can you tell me what fractions you would then have - all with denominator 20?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15/20 - 10/20 + 5/20?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ok, so 15/20 is correct, because you've multiplied top and bottom by 5. question:
Question Text: To make pink paint, you mix red paint with white paint in the ratio \( 3: 4 \). What should replace the star?
Question Image: Red, White, Total | 1200 ml, Star, Blank
Answer A Text: \( 1201 \ \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer B Text: \( 900 \ \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer C Text: \( 4800 \ \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer D Text: \( 1600 \ \mathrm{ml} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Leila! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello!! Can I please get help with this question (â— â€¿â— )'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Of course! Let's take a look together"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜ƒ. Thank you!!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'In the ratio 3:4 which part represented the red paint?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '4 ( I think)'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ah, check the order of the words in the question carefully. because it says we mix red with white it means the red is the first number in the ratio'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So I think since its first 3!! ğŸ˜'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great! so we know we need 3 parts of red and 4 parts of white. we currently have 1200ml of red. Can you use that to work out how much 1 part would be?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm not sure"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So the 1200ml represents the red paint and we know that is 3 parts'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If 1200ml is 3 parts, how could we work out 1 part?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I know now!! SÌ†ÌˆoÌ†Ìˆ wÌ†ÌˆeÌ†Ìˆ cÌ†ÌˆaÌ†ÌˆnÌ†Ìˆ dÌ†ÌˆoÌ†Ìˆ 1200 dÌ†ÌˆiÌ†ÌˆvÌ†ÌˆiÌ†ÌˆdÌ†ÌˆeÌ†ÌˆdÌ†Ìˆ bÌ†ÌˆyÌ†Ìˆ 3 tÌ†ÌˆoÌ†Ìˆ gÌ†ÌˆeÌ†ÌˆtÌ†Ìˆ oÌ†ÌˆnÌ†ÌˆeÌ†Ìˆ pÌ†ÌˆaÌ†ÌˆrÌ†ÌˆtÌ†Ìˆ wÌ†ÌˆhÌ†ÌˆiÌ†ÌˆcÌ†ÌˆhÌ†Ìˆ eÌ†ÌˆqÌ†ÌˆuÌ†ÌˆaÌ†ÌˆlÌ†ÌˆsÌ†Ìˆ 400!! ğŸ˜ğŸ˜'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'amazing ğŸ¥³'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ˜Š thank you ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So the question is asking how much white paint we need. What do you think we'll have to do next?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think we maybe have to do 1200 divided by 4!! ğŸ˜ƒ'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Oo nearly! Thank you for helping me and explaining soooo well!! ğŸ¤©ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're very welcome. Have a great day!"}]

question:
Question Text: Ben and Mila are arguing about equivalent ratios. Ben says \( 4: 10 \) is equivalent to \( 6: 15 \) Mila says \( 4: 10 \) is equivalent to \( 5: 11 \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Ben
Answer B Text: Only Mila
Answer C Text: Both Ben and Mila
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Liana! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Could you please help me with this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course! So for ratios to be equivalent, they must simplify down to the same ratio.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '?? Ok!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '4:10 would simplify to 2:5 if we divide both sides by 2. Can you tell me what 6:15 would simplify to?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '615??'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "To simplify the ratio 6 : 15 we look for something we can divide 6 and 15 by. We can't divide them both by 2..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh yeah i forgot. oh yeah i forgot. kk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What if we divide both sides by 3? 6 : 15 becomes __ : __'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i  dont  know. sorry'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem, let's break it up - what's 6 divided by 3?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3??'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ooh try again'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's it, and 15 divided by 3?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ummm 5?!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab! so 6 : 15 simplifies to 2 : 5 by dividing both sides by 3. That means Ben is right, both of his ratios simplify to 2 : 5 so they are equivalent.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What about Mila, can you simplify 4 : 10 by dividing both sides by 2?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks. 1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite, what's 4 divided by 2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 or 32'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '2 is correct :) And 10 divided by 2?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 or 3*. 1 oe 5. or 3 or 4 or 6 or 7 or 8 or 9. or*'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '5 is correct :) So we took 4 : 10, divided by 2 and got 2 : 5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'YEP'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Last one, Mila's other ratio is 5 : 11"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'kk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can we divide 5 and 11 by anything?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is that 6??'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Actually there's nothing we can divide by, because they are both prime"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So if we divide by 2 or 3 or 5 or anything else we would get decimal answers'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'well im a silly. bit*'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not at all! It was a bit of a sneaky one'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okokokokokokokoooooooooooooooooooooooooookkkkkkk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So that means Mila's ratios simplify to 2:5 and 5:11. They're not the same so she's wrong, they're not equivalent"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'it gliched sorry i meant ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Haha no worries. Key point: both Ben's ratio divide down to 2:5 so he's right, Mila's don't so she is wrong. Ok?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so should i put only ben?? Or ben and mila'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep! Sorry yes to just Ben. Mila's are not the same so she is wrong"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Okie thanks!!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Bye!! Ask for help any time!'}]

Answer C Text: Both Leo and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Question Text: In the diagram, AN : NB \( =3: 5 \)  What is the distance AN?
Question Image: A line that begins with point A, ends with point B, and has point N in between. The entire length of the line measures 48 m.
Answer A Text: \( 16 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer B Text: \( 30 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer C Text: \( 6 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer D Text: \( 18 \mathrm{~m} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi this is Leo again, would you like to go through this question together?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes please'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No worries, it is actually very similar to the last question you just answered'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh. It looks very confusing'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'The line is being split into the ratio 3:5 and we are told that the total length of the line is 48m'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'AN just means the length of the line starting at A and ending at N. How do we split 48 into the ratio 3:5?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'do we do 48 divided by 3 and times by 5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite. In total how many parts has the line been split up into?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'AN represents 3 parts. NB represents 5 parts'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so altogether the line has been split up into 8 parts'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Now we need to find out what one of those parts is worth. 8 parts = 48. 1 part ='}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so the answer is 6?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '6 is one part of the ratio. We want to find the distance AN. How many parts of the ratio is distance AN?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘. 1 part = 6. 3 parts ='}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '18'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘. These questions can be very tricky, you need to look carefully at what amount they are giving you'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so the ratio is 6:3. ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If they are giving you the total then you need to find the total number of parts the ratio has been split up into'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how can we do that?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You would just add the parts of the ratio together'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so 6+3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Here we were told the total length of the line so we needed to add 3 and 5 together to find out that the line had been split up into 8 equal parts'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '48 Ã· 8 = 6'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so 6 was what one part of the ratio was worth'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yea'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So distance AN was 18 as it represented 3 parts of the ratio'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you have any more questions, or should I pass you back to the bot?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no questions at all. thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Brilliant, keep up the great work'}]

question:
Question Text: Dorian and Nathaniel share their profit in a ratio of \( 5: 3 \)  Dorian gets \( Â£ 120 \) more than Nathaniel. How much profit did they make altogether?
Answer A Text: \( Â£ 192 \)
Answer B Text: \( Â£ 480 \)
Answer C Text: \( Â£ 960 \)
Answer D Text: \( Â£ 300 \)

question:
Question Text: In the diagram, \( A X: X B=5: 7 \) What is the distance AX?
Question Image: A diagram of a straight line between A and B. X lies part way along the line. The total distance from A to B is given as 240cm
Answer A Text: \( 48 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer B Text: \( 140 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( 20 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer D Text: \( 100 \mathrm{~cm} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Lila, would you like to look at this one together, or are you happy having a go on your own?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Can we look at this together please'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course!ğŸ˜Š. Is sharing in a ratio new for you, or are you revising it?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'It is new for me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ooh great you're challenging yourself! The ratio in this question is 5:7. That means 5 parts of the line are between A and X, then 7 parts of the line are between X and B. I know that's a bit odd because there are no parts marked on the line, but that's what the ratio is saying. If there are 5 parts and 7 parts, how many parts of the line does that make altogether?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5+7=12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Exactly! Altogether, we're splitting this 240cm line into 12 parts. What calculation do you think we will do next, if we're splitting 240cm into 12?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '240 divided by 12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. Do you know the answer to that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Erm 20'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab ğŸ˜ That means when the line is split into 12 parts, each part is 20cm. How many parts are between A and X again? From the ratio?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So can you guess the calculation for the distance AX, that we're trying to find?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '20x5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's it!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So  100?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's the one. To recap: We added up the parts 5+7 = 12, then we divided the total 240/12=20, then we multiplied by the side of the ratio we wanted, 5x20 = 100. Any questions about why we did those steps?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No thanks so much'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You are very welcome, keep up the good work and ask for help anytime!'}]

question:
Question Text: Jack and Sophie are arguing about percentages. Jack says \( 45 \%>0.059 \) Sophie says \( 45 \%>\frac{16}{31} \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: Mia and Bruce are discussing mental multiplication strategies. Mia says \( 22 \times 9=22 \times 10-22 \) Bruce says \( 22 \times 9=(20 \times 9)+9 \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Mia
Answer B Text: Only Bruce
Answer C Text: Both Mia and Bruce
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello. Hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'hI THERE! :). *Hi there. Ha sorry. How can I help? :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Last Questions given to me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I can see you initially chose both of them were correct, however that's not correct"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes. Why'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So firstly let's look at Mia, she's doing 22x10 - 22. So 10 lots of 22 subtract 1 lot of 22, means we have 9 lots of 22. Is that one correct? :)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Nope'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "She says that its equal to 22 x 9, so that is correct. It doesn't matter if we write it as 22 x 9 or 9 x 22, that gives us the same answer :)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "okie doke, so next we have Bruce, he's doing (20 x 9) + 9. So this time we're doing lots of 9. Firstly he does 20 lots of 9, and then adds 1 lot of 9"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How many lots of 9 has he got in total then?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite, he does 20 lots of 9, and then adds 1 lot of 9. How many bags do we have in total?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '21'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Excellent :) well done. So overall we have Mia is correct, and Bruce in incorrect'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oooooooooooh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Which answer will we need to pick?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'A'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Does that make more sense now? ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I love you so much thanks for helping me out'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem at all! It doesn't matter if we write it as 22 x 9 or 9 x 22, that gives us the same answer :)", 'student': 'Yes'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': "okie doke, so next we have Bruce, he's doing (20 x 9) + 9. So this time we're doing lots of 9. Firstly he does 20 lots of 9, and then adds 1 lot of 9", 'student': 'Yes'}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': 'How many lots of 9 has he got in total then?', 'student': '2'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': 'Not quite, he does 20 lots of 9, and then adds 1 lot of 9.
