So that's the same as doing 21 x 9, he said it's the same as 22 x 9, so is he correct?", 'student': 'Yes'}, {'turn': 9, 'teacher': 'Are you sure? 21 x 9 = 22 x 9?', 'student': 'Nope'}, {'turn': 10, 'teacher': 'Ok, so 21 lots of something is not the same as 22 lots, so that means Bruce is incorrect :). Have a great rest of your day ğŸ˜Š', 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: Rio and Luke are discussing mental division strategies.  Rio says one way to divide by \( \mathbf{5 0} \) is to divide by \( \mathbf{1 0} \) and then divide by \( 10 \). Luke says one way to divide by \( \mathbf{5 0} \) is to multiply by \( 2 \) and then divide by \( 100 \).  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Rio
Answer B Text: Only Luke
Answer C Text: Both Rio and Luke
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Now we would have had to exchange from our hundreds column can you think of anything that would make 1? - 4 = 9'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So what is 9 +4?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '13'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super so we must have done 13-4....so we had a three. But remember we exchanged 1 from this column  so originally it would not have been 3, it would have been???'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2. 4*'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'The opposite way, yes well done Safiya!! It must have been 4 :). question:
Question Text: Liam is thinking of a number.  It is a prime number and it is a multiple of \( 9 \).  What is Liam's number?
Answer A Text: \( 99 \)
Answer B Text: \( 29 \)
Answer C Text: \( 9 \)
Answer D Text: There are no such numbers
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Emma'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Pls can i have help on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So we know it is a multiple of 9 and also a prime number Lets see if we can spot which numbers are multiples of 9 in the list. Can you see any?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'When they are multiples of 9 does that mean they are in the timetable'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes well done :) they are part of the 9 times tables'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ‘. I cant see any'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's ok well I can see 99, that would be 9 x 11, do you agree?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh ye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Now would 99 be prime? Do you remember what a prime number is?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'N. Ye. 99 is not prime'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No 99 is not prime. any multiple of 9 must mean 9 is a factor. Any thoughts on the others?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '29'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So is 29 part of the 9 times tables'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Nope. 9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok great but is 9 prime?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No. So is it d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No so that leaves us with D. Emma that is because if a number is a multiple of 9 it must mean 9 is a factor so it can't be prime as prime is only when it has two factors, 1 and itself. Does that make sense ok?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Would you like to return to answer the question'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}]

question:
Question Text: Leo and Emma are arguing about how to leave answers to some fractions questions they are working on.  Leo says he is going to leave one of his answers as \( \frac{143}{2} \)  Emma says she is going to leave one of her answers as \( \frac{4.2}{9} \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Leo
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: Write \( 12 \) over \( 15 \) as a fraction in its simplest terms.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{12}{15} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{4}{5} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{3}{5} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{4} \)

Are you trying to do the '12 over 15' question?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes. i need to get t know u'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So how would we write that as a fraction to start with, before we think about simplifying?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'you write one  number at top one at bottom'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab! Can that be simplified at all'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yh. 4/5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! Because we can divide both numbers by 3. It seems like you've got it :). I'll hand you back so you can try the next question!"}]

question:
Question Text: Simplify fully (if possible):
Question Text: \( \frac{42}{56} \)
Answer A Text: \( \frac{3}{4} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{21}{28} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{6}{8} \)
Answer D Text: Cannot be simplified
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Are you the one from last time'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I've helped you before, but I think that was a while ago..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Ok. So. How do I know what I'm simply by"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Well to simplify fully you need to divide by the biggest common factor you can find. So you're trying to think of the biggest number that goes into 42 and 56"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "So like 56 Ã· something then times that answer then that's ut. Oh. Nvm. No I dont. Understand"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can you think of anything that you could divide 42 and 56 by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ã· by 2. 112. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "What's 42 divided by 2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '21'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yep, and 56 divided by 2?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '112'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite, try dividing the 50 and the 6 separately'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '103'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "What's 50 divided by 2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25. Oh now I get it I was doing it wrong'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ah I see you were multiplying instead of dividing! We want to divide everything. So yep, can you try dividing 56 by 2 again now?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm very tired today"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '28'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Good :D so 42/56 simplifies to 21/28. Can you see anything that we could divide 21 and 28 by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No. Wait. 50. Something'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite, remember we want to divide them... What times table has 21 and 28 in?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "7 for 28 and you can't do 21. I don't think you can do 21"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ah you can do 7 in both!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohhh yeah'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So from 21/28 we get down to...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '7'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yep so divide them both by 7 and you will get the simplified fraction'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '4and 3. 3/4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's it! So 42/56 in its simplest form is 3/4."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Good to go, or would you like an other example?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'GTG'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab, bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: Write two and four ninths as an improper fraction.
Answer A Text: \( 2 \frac{4}{9} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{22}{9} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{24}{9} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{8}{9} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there! So, an improper fraction. Is one where the numerator is larger than the denominator'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Write two and four ninths as an improper fraction is the question I am stuck on. What. what do u mean'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So, the answer will be B or C, because an "improper fraction"'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think it is A'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'is one where the top number is larger than the bottom number. A is called a "mixed number". An improper fraction is one where the top number is larger than the bottom number. So, what we need to do is... work out how many ninths we have altogether'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'And how do u do that'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How many ninths in 2 wholes?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '18'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Or 16'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, 18....2 x 9. And then we have the extra 4/9. So, altogether, how many ninths?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '22'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Fab! So, it's 22/9. Is this ok?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So B. Yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes! Great work Saniya!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yay!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Bye for now!'}]

question:
Question Text: What should replace the star? \( \frac{1}{4} \text { of } \color{yellow}\bigstar\)\(=20 \)
Answer A Text: \( 60 \)
Answer B Text: \( 24 \)
Answer C Text: \( 5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 80 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Saffron. How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello! Please can I have help with this question-'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of cours. *course'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thank you!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, we're told that 1/4 of something is 20. and we need to work out what the something is. question:
Question Text: Leo and Lila are discussing fractions, decimals and percentages.
Question Text: Leo says \( 0.35=\frac{7}{20} \)
Question Text: Lila says \( 0.35=3.5 \% \)
Question Text: Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Leo
Answer B Text: Only Lila
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Lila
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: Which region is impossible to fill with a percentage?
Question Image: A Venn diagram with two sets overlapping. They are labelled 'Bigger than 0.15' and 'Smaller than 1/4'. A is in the 'Bigger than 0.15' only. B is in the intersection. C is in the 'Smaller than 1/4' only. D is outside the sets but included in the universal set.
Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D

question:
Question Text: Which region is impossible to fill with a percentage?
Question Image: A Venn diagram with two sets overlapping. They are labelled 'Bigger than 0.15' and 'Smaller than 1/4'. A is in the 'Bigger than 0.15' only. B is in the intersection. C is in the 'Smaller than 1/4' only. D is outside the sets but included in the universal set.
Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D

question:
Question Text: Jack and Lisa are discussing negative numbers.  Jack says \( (-2)^{17} \) is positive.  Lisa says \( (-2)^{24} \) is positive.  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Lisa
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Lisa
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: \( 1+2 \times 3^{4}= \)
Question Text: Which calculation should you do first?
Answer A Text: \( 1+2 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \times 3 \)
Answer C Text: \( 3^{4} \)

question:
Question Text: A distance rounded to the nearest metre is \( 98 \mathrm{~m} \). Which one of the following could that distance be?
Answer A Text: \( 985.9 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer B Text: \( 9848 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( 9869 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer D Text: \( 978.1 \mathrm{~cm} \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': "I don't understand the question"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Catherine!  Let me have a look at it.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok. Hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So it looks like we are rounding here!  And it looks like we have meters and centimeters. Do you know how to convert between cm and m?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you know how many centimetres are in a metre?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No. Is it 1000'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Close!  There are 100 cm in a m.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'K. Is it b'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It is B!  Nice job!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Would you like any explanation, or do you feel good to go back?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Explanation pls'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If we rewrite 9848 cm into metres, it becomes 98.48 m. We can do that because we know 1 m = 100 cm.  That means we would move the decimal twice, since 100 changes the place value two times. Then, if we round 98.48 to the nearest number, it would be 98 m.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We round down when it is less than 98.5, and otherwise we would round up to 99. Can I help any further?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes what do u mean round down pls'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'There is a video if you scroll up that may explain rounding better than I can.  Would you mind watching it, and then can come back and ask any more questions you have?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'OK thanks. Can I go back'}]

question:
Question Text: A distance rounded to the nearest metre is \( 98 \mathrm{~m} \). Which one of the following could that distance be?
Answer A Text: \( 985.9 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer B Text: \( 9848 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( 9869 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer D Text: \( 978.1 \mathrm{~cm} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Elara!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im a bit stuck on how to round up with decimals'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So the same rules apply as when you are rounding whole numbers, that if the next digit is 5 or above we round up. So for example in answer A, we would round up to 986'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'but if there is not a decimal . how do we know which number to round up'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Can you convert 986cm to m? I'm not sure what you mean... Like in answer B? Ok yes so the key thing here is that we're rounding to the nearest metre. Do you know how many centimetres that is?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1000 cm in a metre'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite, it's 100! 1000 is for m in a km or lots of others, cm are a weird one ğŸ˜"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh yesğŸ˜…'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So really when it says round to the nearest metre, we are rounding to the nearest 100cm'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'In option B, we are rounding 9848 to the nearest 100. What would that be?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9800'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent, and how many metres is that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '98'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect! So the answer is B! We can check C to make sure it makes sense though. Can you use the same steps to round 9869cm to the nearest metre?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'with decimals how do we round'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Go to the nearest 100cm just like before. 9869 to the nearest 100 is 9900, so 99m.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'but with 985.9 what do we do'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "We are still rounding to the nearest 100cm, so really you can ignore the decimal, as it's not next to the hundreds digit. If you are rounding the 9 at the beginning, only the 8 affects what you do"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'we round up because 8 is above 5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yep exactly, so 985.9 rounds up to 1000. It would be the same if we rounded 985, without the decimal'}]

question:
Question Text: Lila and Nolan share some sweets in the ratio \( 6: 15 \)  Which of the following ratios is not equivalent to this?
Answer A Text: \( 18: 45 \)
Answer B Text: \( 14: 35 \)
Answer C Text: \( 9: 18 \)
Answer D Text: \( 2: 5 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Joshua!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi is it d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'll just look... No, D IS equivalent because..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'its a then'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "If we divide 6 and 15 both by 3, we would get 2:5. Can you explain why you think it's A? Remember, that we get equivalent ratio the same way that we get equivalent fractions..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'because i have a mate who swaid it is'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ğŸ˜‚ Ok, let's use our thinking skills instead. How can we work out what an equivalent ratio is?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'A ratio will be equivalent to 6:15...if we multiply (or divide) both numbers by the same number...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'itssssss c'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So, 6:15 is equivalent to 18:45 because both 6 and 15 have been multiplied by ? Why is it C?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'because its the last one'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hmmm....well as I said, it's the correct answer if it's not equivalent to 6:15..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We know that 6:15 can be simplified to 2:5 by dividing both sides by 3. So, you can check which ratio is not equivalent to 2:5... 18:45 IS equivalent to 2:5...because both numbers have been multiplied by ??'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'd'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You've now guessed them all...I was hoping you'd work out the correct answer with me. Shall I let you get back to the lesson? ğŸ˜€"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes pls if its d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It's not d.... Becuase I've told you that 2:5 IS equivalent to 6:15...you need the one that is NOT equivalent. Which set of numbers is not a multiple of 2 and 5?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'c'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep! I'll leave you to it, keep up the good work!"}]

question:
Question Text: Lucia and Nathaniel share some sweets in the ratio \( 3: 2 \)  There are \( 60 \) sweets in total.  How many sweets does Lucia receive?
Answer A Text: \( 20 \)
Answer B Text: \( 24 \)
Answer C Text: \( 12 \)
Answer D Text: \( 36 \)

question:
Question Text: Jack and Sophie are arguing about surds.  Jack says \( \sqrt{1} \) is a surd.  Sophie says \( \sqrt{2} \) is a surd. Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Answer A Text: \( 2 a^{2} \)
Answer B Text: \( 3 a \)
Answer C Text: \( a^{3} \)
Answer D Text: Does not simplify

question:
Question Text: Simplify as much as possible: \( \frac{6 a}{4 a^{2}} \)
Answer A Text: \( 2 a \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{3 a}{2} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{3}{2} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{3}{2 a} \)

question:
Question Text: A taxi driver charges an initial \( Â£ 2.50 \) plus \( Â£ 1.20 \) per mile travelled. Which of the following expressions is correct for the total cost, \( T \), of a journey of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) miles?
Answer A Text: \( \mathrm{T}=2.50 \mathrm{~m}+1.20 \)
Answer B Text: \( \mathrm{T}=1.20 \mathrm{~m}+2.50 \)
Answer C Text: \( \mathrm{T}=1.20(2.50+m) \)
Answer D Text: \( \mathrm{T}=3.70 \mathrm{~m} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Isabella! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'idk what it would be or how 5to work it out'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, no worries, let's have a look together."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So, the taxi charges Â£1.20 per mile travelled. So, how would you calculate the total charge if someone travelled, say 5 miles? What sum would you do?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1.20 x5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great!  so you've multiplied the number of miles by 1.2.  Perfect. So, if the number of miles is represented by m.  How do you write that sum now?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'would it be c'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite....everyone gets an initial charge of Â£2.50 so you need to add that on to the calculation for the charge for miles. So, m is the number of miles and you said to multiply that by 1.2, so that part is 1.2m and then you also need to add on the Â£2.50 initial charge.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, no worries. So, the total cost is made up of two separate costs. Everyone has to pay an initial cost of Â£2.50.  This never changes. Then there's the part of the cost that changes according to how far you travel. So, like you correctly said, if you travel miles, you get charged 1.20x5."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So, if you travelled 5 miles, your total cost, T would be: 2.50 + (1.20x5). question:
Question Text: Expand: \[ 3(p+1) \]
Answer A Text: \( 3 p+3 \)
Answer B Text: \( 3 p+1 \)
Answer C Text: \( p+3 \)
Answer D Text: \( 3 p+4 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Lucy! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi. Iâ€™m a little stuck on the algebra questions'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, have you done expanding brackets like this before?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Iâ€™m not too sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's fine, all this question means is multiply each term inside the bracket by 3. So first we do 3 times p. How do we write that?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3p?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect, and then 3 x 1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '31'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite, though I can see why you said that - we don't need to follow the same rules when we're just multiplying numbers. So 3 x 1 is a normal multiplication"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh ok. Can we practice a little more so i can properly remember please?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course, so this one would be 3xp and 3x1 giving us 3p + 3. What about 2(p+5)? We need to do 2 times p and 2 times 5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh! But what do the brackets mean again?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'They are telling you "here are the bits to multiply by 2"'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Is it always 2 or just in this case?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If it just said 2p + 5 with no brackets, only the p is multiplied by 2. Just in this example. You multiply by whatever is at the front'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Alright. Thank you so much!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're welcome! Do you want another example, or do you feel ready to go on?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Mmh maybe another one could help me understand more'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course! So we had 3(p+1) = 3p +3 and 2(p+5) = 2p+10. What about 5(p+3)?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Is it 5p +3?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Close but don't forget to multiply 5 x 3! Check my examples to help ğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok. 5p + 15?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's it!!! ğŸ‰ğŸ‘ğŸ‰ğŸ‘. Well done :). Feeling more confident now? Do you want one more?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think I finally got it! Yes:))'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Fab! Let's try 10(p+2)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Do I have to times the 2 by 10?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes :D'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '10p +20?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect, well done!!! Sometimes it will be a minus sign in the bracket, so then your answer has a minus sign too, like 4(g-10) would be 4g - 40. Does that make sense?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh ok. Yes it does make sense'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Feeling ready to try the next question in the lesson?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Fab, I'm here if you need me for any more help :). Bye!"}]

question:
Question Text: Expand: \[ -(1-2 p) \]
Answer A Text: \( -1+2 p \)
Answer B Text: \( -1-2 p \)
Answer C Text: \( 1+2 p \)
Answer D Text: \( 1-2 p \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Lila, how can I help :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "hi there, I don't understand the negatives in this question. can you help me, please, thank you ğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem at all, of course I can. Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: What should replace the star and triangle when this expression is fully factorised?
Question Text: \( 6 m-9 \equiv {\bigstar}(\triangle m-\bigcirc) \)
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=6 \\ \Delta=1\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=2 \\ \Delta=3\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=3 \\ \Delta=3\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=3 \\ \Delta=2\end{array} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How are you getting on with this question? ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont get it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so if we look at 6m and 9, what number do they have as a common factor?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'superb. so 3(....). what would be inside?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2m+9. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '2m is perfect. 3(2m - ...). the ... is 3 x ? = 9'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3(2m-3)'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'you got it! so we need the star and triangle, so which one you going for?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'b. is that right?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '3(2m-3) the star is in front of the bracket, have another look'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im comfused. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So 3(2m-3) is correct. star(traingle m - circle). is the other bit. So which number matches the star?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok thank you. a. ? is it a'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'compare 3(2m-3) and star(triangle m - circle). The star is outside the bracket. like our 3. so star = 3'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohhhhh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'the triangle is the first number inside. like our 2. so triangle = 2. does that make more sense?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, they are odd questions!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ye they are'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "it's easier to just factorise than do the shapes!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done for sticking with it! Bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the star? \( m(m+2)(m-2) \equiv m^{3} \bigstar \  m^{2} \triangle \ m \)
Answer A Text: \( \bigstar=+0 \) (no \( \mathrm{m}^{2} \) term)
Answer B Text: \( \bigstar=+2 \)
Answer C Text: \( \bigstar=-2 \)
Answer D Text: \( \bigstar=-4 \)

I'm confused about this question"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Oh yeah it's definitely stepped up a level with the extra m!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'I think the best way to do it is to multiply out the double bracket like we started doing before, and then multiply your answer by m.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So first will be m times m, then 2 times m, m times -2, and 2 times -2. Let me know when you have an answer to that.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so it would be m + 2-2+4 ????'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'I think you lost some ms!! Your numbers are all correct though'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "m+2 m-2+4 ??? I don't know"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Almost there: m squared + 2m - 2m -4'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh I get that'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent :D. Can you see how that expression could simplify? Anything that might cancel out?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so for the answer its +2? so for the answer its +2? then'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It would be if we just had +2m! But we have +2m and -2m'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so -4. d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Nearly there, that would be if we had -2m -2m. What is +2 -2? So what is 2 - 2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "oh hahah so its +0 that's sneaky"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Right!!! Definitely sneaky. We got 0m from the double bracket, so once we multiply by m it's still 0."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh ok thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You are very welcome, well done on persevering with that one! question:
Question Text: Elijah is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Elijah's book. Elijah always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation. What operation should replace the star?
Question Image: A diagram with an arrow from 7x to x labelled with an arrow and the arrow is labelled with a star
Answer A Text: \( +7 \)
Answer B Text: \( \times 7 \)
Answer C Text: \( \div 7 \)
Answer D Text: \( -7 \)

question:
Question Text: Solve the equation:  \( 3 p=\frac{1}{12} \)
Answer A Text: \( p=\frac{1}{4} \)
Answer B Text: \( p=\frac{1}{36} \)
Answer C Text: \( p=4 \)
Answer D Text: \( p=\frac{1}{9} \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'HI!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again Nina!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'please can you help me with this question?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Sure, give me a moment to have a look at it.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok sure!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What do you need to do to 3p to get p on its own?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'divide?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Divide by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'p'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'That would leave 3 on its own. You want p.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okkk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So what should we divide 3p by to get p on its own?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/12?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hmmm.. not quite. If we've got 3p and we want p, we need to divide by 3. 3p / 3 = p"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'OHHHHHH! wait. so I divide it by 3?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You do! Then what happens on the other side?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm not sureğŸ˜–ğŸ˜–ğŸ˜–"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We must do the same to both sides of the equation so that it remains true so if we divide one side by 3, we must do the same to the other side.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so we divide the other side by 3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We do!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yayyy'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What do you get?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hmmm.... sorry not sureğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£ğŸ˜£'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '1/12 divided by 3. How do we divide with fractions?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/36? I mean the answer?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Correct! question:
Question Text: Solve the equation: \[ 0.45=0.3 p \]
Answer A Text: \( p=\frac{2}{3} \)
Answer B Text: \( p=1.5 \)
Answer C Text: \( p=0.135 \)
Answer D Text: \( p=0.15 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Michael, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im stuck on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, do you know what sum you need to do to solve this equation?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no not realy'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's look at it with easier numbers first.  So, if instead, it said  6=3p. What would the value of p be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great! What sum did you do?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6/3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So, for solving 0.45=0.3p, what sum do you need to do?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.45/0.3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great.... How shall we work this out?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is the answer 0.15'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No, you've got the right numbers but we need to think about place value, or what looks right... how many times does 0.3 go into 0.45? 1x0.3 = 0.3 2x0.3 = 0.6. So, because 0.45 is between 0.3 and 0.6, the answer must be between 1 and 2. Does this make sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no not realy'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, you asked if the answer is 0.15 and it's a useful skill to know if our answer looks about the right size....so we're trying to see how many 0.3s go into 0.45... 1 x 0.3=0.3"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'but 2x0.3=0.6 which is bigger than 0.45...so 15 x 0.3 will be far too big. Another way to think about it.... Is to use whole numbers in the sum....'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it a. A'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No, you've got the correct digits. when you said 15, you had the right digits, it's just that that answer is too big."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it 1.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes....you could perhaps consider doing a topic on calculations with decimals later so that you can see a video explanation of how to to this type of sum. I'll leave you to it, keep up the good work! ğŸ™‚"}]

question:
Question Text: Jack and Lily are arguing about a first step to solve this equation: \( 4(m-1)=20 \) Jack says you can write: \( 4 m=21 \) Lily says you can write: \( m-1=5 \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Lily
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Lily
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Nina! Ok, so you went for both were incorrect.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "i got the answer x = 6 but what i did doesn't match any option. i did 4 x m and 4 x -1. i got 4m - 4 = 20. Add 4 to both sides. 4m = 24"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's brilliant! ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ The thing is with these questions there is often more than one way to do them. So although your way is perfect, one or both of theirs may work too!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm confused?"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So Jack added 1 to both sides. Are we allowed to do that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Your way expanding the brackets first, which is great. If you DON'T EXPAND the brackets, you have to undo the last operation that happened first."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohh okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So what happened last? x4? or +1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Im not sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So if you look from the letter. If starts with m. then it becomes m-1. then 4(m-1). so it was -1, then x4. So if you go backwards, what is the opposite of the last thing I typed?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '/4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. So you can do that to both sides, but you CANNOT add 1. So has Lily /4 correctly?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So she is right! Is Jack allowed to +1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So we don't need to check his work, as it's wrong regardless. So if I gave you 6(m+2)=54. Are you allowed to expand to solve?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6m + 12 = 54. i expanded and now i have to work out what m is. 54 - 12 is 42. 6 x _ is 42. m = 7'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! Can you -2 to solve?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Solve what?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'The same question. Are you allowed to -2 from both sides? 6(m+2)=54'}]

question:
Question Text: Alex and Sophie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation: \( 4(m-1)=20 \) Alex says you can write: \( 4 m=21 \) Sophie says you can write: \( m-1=5 \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Alex
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Alex and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'please can i have help still. im not sure about this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course! :). No problem, so what do you think Alex has done first to get 4m = 21?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'he has done 20 +1 and 4 X m'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great :) He has indeed! Is this a correct step? :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "i'm not sure ;D"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It is not, because if we expand those brackets out, we actually have 4m - 4, so adding 1 just means we should have 4m-3 on the left'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thank you! is that all lad?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "If you think you have an answer, then yes. But I'm not sure you do have an answer?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Is it D'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm afraid it isn't"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it C ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'I think we already said one of them is incorrect?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so which one is it? im still not sure i understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Me neither :). So we said that Alex is incorrect, because he should really have expanded his brackets first. Then we need to look at what Sophie has done. How do you think she's got from 20 to 5?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'she has divided 20 by 4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And the left has become m-1 instead of 4(m-1). Is that correct? :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok. yes. db. sorry acident'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So Alex is wrong, Sophie is correct :). I'll let you pop that answer in! :)"}]

question:
Question Text: Solve the equation: \( 0.4 t-0.2=1 \)
Answer A Text: \( t=0.32 \)
Answer B Text: \( t=3 \)
Answer C Text: \( t=2 \)
Answer D Text: \( t=0.48 \)

question:
Question Text: Solve the equation: \( \frac{t+1}{3}=\frac{5}{4} \)
Answer A Text: \( t=2 \frac{3}{4} \)
Answer B Text: \( t=-\frac{7}{12} \)
Answer C Text: \( t=\frac{3}{4} \)
Answer D Text: \( t=\frac{11}{12} \)

question:
Question Text: Leo and Mia are arguing about a first step to solve this equation: \(9 v+1=4 v-3\)  Leo says you can write: \( 5 v+1=-3 \)  Mia says you can write: \( 9 v=4 v-4 \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Leo
Answer B Text: Only Mia
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Mia
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi, would you like some help with this one?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'whats the awnser'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We can work it out together.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i do not understand so please may you tell me the answer'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What has Leo done to the left hand side of the equation to go from 9v + 1 to 5v + 1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I do not know what has Leo done can you just tell me the awnser'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I won't just tell you the answer, but we can definitely go through it together"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No tell me the awnser because you are not making sense'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "We can see that the only thing that has changed is the number of 'v's. How many has he taken away to go from 9v to 5v?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'take away 4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent ğŸ˜€. So on the left he took away 4vs.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "let's look at the right hand side. I know the awnser it is c'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'll hand you back - great work!"}]

question:
Question Text: Liam and Emma are arguing about how to solve this equation:   \( x^{2}+4 x=0 \)  Liam says one solution is \( x=2 \)  Emma says one solution is \( x=0 \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Liam
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Liam and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: Max and Lila are discussing the sequence: \[ 3,9,15,21,27,33,39, \ldots \]  Max says the \( 100^{\text {th }} \) term is odd.  Lila says the \( 100^{\text {th }} \) term is a multiple of \( 3 \). Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Max
Answer B Text: Only Lila
Answer C Text: Both Max and Lila
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: What is the gradient of this line?
Question Image: A straight line graph on squared paper, showing all four quadrants. Line goes through (-1, -1) and (0,1) and extends both sides.
Answer A Text: \( 2 \)
Answer B Text: \( 1 \)
Answer C Text: \( -2 \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{2} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hello Ayla! Let's have a look at the question"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi I m stuck on how to work out the gradient'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So for every 1 it goes across how many squares is it going up? The Gradient of a line shows how steep it is'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'its going up 1 square?..'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite as the graph went from (0,1) it went up to (1,3) so for every 1 it goes across it goes 2 up. Does that make sense? So gradient would be 2 (not negative as it went 2 up not down)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Im struggling to understand really.. sorry im really bad at this'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No it's fine do not apologise Ayla ğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Maybe i could watch a video and come back to you?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes sure, do that and come back to me if you're still stuck! I'll let you practise more questions now then ğŸ‘‹"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ˜„ğŸ˜„'}]

the y coordinate here is 0'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so the coordinate is (-0.5, 0)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohh ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', coordinate (first value) will change'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'and if we move up or down, the y coordinate (second value) will change'}, {'role': question:
Question Text: What is the gradient of this line?
Question Image: A graph with x axis from -3 to 8 and y axis from -3 to 3. A green line from top left sloping down to bottom right, going through the y axis at 2 and the x axis at 6
Answer A Text: \( -2 \)
Answer B Text: \( -3 \)
Answer C Text: \( -1.5 \)
Answer D Text: \( -\frac{1}{3} \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi SophieğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How are you getting on with this question? ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'not too well. i cant worgbkuh=. sorry'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Has the video helped at all?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'that was geoffrey. not really. what is the equation for the gradient?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Depending how you've been taught it either: difference in y / difference in x. or rise/run"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'elaborate. can i just have the answer please im stuck'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So we need to fins two points with nice, preferable whole number coordinates'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3, 1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Amazing, and another one?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0, 6? is that right?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '6,0?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh ye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So across to 6, 0 up or down'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'my bad. 6 across 0 up'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, so we have (3,1) and (6,0)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Now we can work out he gradient by subtracting the y coordinates. So 1- 0. then the x coordinates. so 3-6'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'its 1. then -3. ğŸ˜ğŸ˜'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Brilliant, then the gradient is the y answer/the x answer. so 1/-3. so which answer do you think we are going for?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '- o.e reocurring? -0.3 reocurring. SOPHIE COME BACK. SOPHIE!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Take a look at the 4 answers'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'which is the same as 1/-3?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '- 1/3???'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'There we go :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Cheers'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So for gradient 1) find some nice points 2) subtract ys 3) subtract xs 4) do y/x. That should help :). Bye Julian!'}]

dialogue: [{'turn': 0, 'teacher': '', 'student': 'hi SophieğŸ‘'}, {'turn': 1, 'teacher': 'Hi! How are you getting on with this question? ğŸ˜Š', 'student': 'not too well. i cant worgbkuh=. sorry'}, {'turn': 2, 'teacher': 'Has the video helped at all?', 'student': 'that was geoffrey. not really. what is the equation for the gradient?'}, {'turn': 3, 'teacher': "Depending how you've been taught it either: difference in y / difference in x. or rise/run", 'student': 'elaborate. can i just have the answer please im stuck'}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': 'So we need to fins two points with nice, preferable whole number coordinates', 'student': '3, 1'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': 'Amazing, and another one?', 'student': '0, 6? is that right?'}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': '6,0?', 'student': 'oh ye'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': 'So across to 6, 0 up or down', 'student': 'my bad. 6 across 0 up'}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': 'Great, so we have (3,1) and (6,0)', 'student': 'ye'}, {'turn': 9, 'teacher': 'Now we can work out he gradient by subtracting the y coordinates. So 1- 0. then the x coordinates. so 3-6', 'student': 'its 1. then -3. ğŸ˜ğŸ˜'}, {'turn': 10, 'teacher': 'Brilliant, then the gradient is the y answer/the x answer. so 1/-3. so which answer do you think we are going for?', 'student': '- o.e reocurring? -0.3 reocurring. SOPHIE COME BACK. SOPHIE!'}, {'turn': 11, 'teacher': 'Take a look at the 4 answers', 'student': 'thanks'}, {'turn': 12, 'teacher': 'which is the same as 1/-3?', 'student': '- 1/3???'}, {'turn': 13, 'teacher': 'There we go :)', 'student': 'Cheers'}, {'turn': 14, 'teacher': 'So for gradient 1) find some nice points 2) subtract ys 3) subtract xs 4) do y/x. That should help :). Bye Julian!', 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: What is the equation of this curve?
Question Image: A quadratic curve that passes through (-1,0) and (2,0) on the x-axis.
Answer A Text: \( y=x^{2}-2 \)
Answer B Text: \( y=x^{2}-2 x \)
Answer C Text: \( y=(x-1)(x+2) \)
Answer D Text: \( y=(x+1)(x-2) \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Tomas, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello I donâ€™t understand ths question I never did this before\\'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, let me have a look at the graph. Have you studied solving equations in factorised form?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I donâ€™t know, maybe?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What the graph is showing us is that when x is -1, y = 0 and the same when x = 2. Can you see what I mean?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Absolutely not]'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Haha no problem. Where does the curved graph cross the x axis? The axis going across?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Is it at 0,-1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '(-1, 0) but yep, and the other place?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2,0. Pretty sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Exactly. So those coordinates say x is -1, y is 0, and then x is 2 and y is 0. Right?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yeah. so in the equation y needs to equal 0. and x=1?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Exactly, the equation of the graph is y =, and where the line crosses the axis is where that equals 0. So we're looking for an equation where putting in x = 1 would make it equal 0"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok i see'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Sorry x = -1!! No 1, because it crossed at -1.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oposd. oops. Its ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Sorry about that, I scrolled back up to the question and realised my mistake.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh its ok I can do that too'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Have you decided which equation in the question would give us 0 when we put in x = -1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Iâ€™m thinking. Iâ€™m thinking. hmmm'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No rush ğŸ˜Š Try substituting x = -1 into each one.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i can eliminate a and b because b=3 and a=-1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Excellent, they don't work at all."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'also for c and d when i work out the answers for what is in the brackets do i times them'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes that's right"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'It is d. I got -3 in the brackets and 0, i times them together and it is 0'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "D looks good! Let's just check it works for the other crossing point - do you get 0 if x = 2 as well?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Uh. nope. you get 3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Are you sure?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'not reallt'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'I got 3 for the first bracket, but the second bracket is...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So when we multiply them we get?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'its because i thought x=3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ahhh ok'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'silly mistake lol. 0'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Lol easily done'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks i think i understand no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So yes, the answer is definitely D! To help you in the rest of the lesson, can you link between the graph and the equation? The graph crosses the x axis at -1 and 2, the equation had x+1 and x-2. They are always going to be opposites like that, in any question like this. So that's something to look out for :)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh ok I understand you can take me back too Eedi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, bye! ğŸ‘‹'}]

question:
Question Image: Two points on a coordinate grid, labelled (4,10 and (4,4)
Question Text: Jack and Lily are discussing what coordinates would complete a square.  Jack says \( (9,4) \) and \( (9,10) \) Lily says \( (1,7) \) and \( (7,7) \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Lily
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Lily
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there Mariana! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Hello, I'm not quite sure about the width and length of the square"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, lets have a look!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So if we went with Jack's (9,4) and (9, 10), the other coordinates are (4,10) and (4,4). If we look at the first numbers... 4 and 9. what is the difference between these numbers?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super! what about the difference between the 2nd numbers?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super. Now, in a square.. all the sides are the same length. So do you think Jack is correct?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No because 5 and 6 are different values'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Super! Well done. Now Lily's is a little harder... lets think about if we were going from (4,4) to (1, 7). We need to go 3 across and 3 up. Can you see how I am getting that?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes - I think so'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So we need to see if that pattern would continue for each of the coordinates. How about going from (4,4) to (7,7)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'You add 3 to each so go up by 3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So it is the same as the previous one. And again, if we are going from (7,7) to (4,10). We'd still be going 3 across and 3 up, wouldn't we?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So we do the same pattern each time by the same number. So what about Lily, do you think this will form a square?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes - it is forming the same pattern each time. Thank you!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super! So lily is correct! No problem at all! :) Great work Marianaâ­â­â­â­â­'}]

question:
Question Text: What is the height of the rectangle as indicated by the arrow?
Question Image: A pair of axes with no labels. 4 points are marked and joined with straight lines to make a rectangle. The top right corner of the rectangle is labelled with co-ordinate (1,5).  The bottom left corner of the rectangle is labelled with co-ordinate (-3,-15). A double-ended arrow spans the height of the rectangle from (-3,15) up to the corner of the rectangle directly above (-3,15).
Answer A Text: \( 10 \)
Answer B Text: \( 20 \)
Answer C Text: \( 4 \)
Answer D Text: \( 2 \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Am stuck on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok, the height of this rectangle will be the distance from the bottom to the top, and we can use the y coordinates to work that out'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So the bottom of the rectangle is at -15, what is the y-coordinate of the top?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite, that's the x-coordinate at the bottom. Have a look at the top of the rectangle, and the y-coordinate is the second number in the brackets"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So now we want the difference between -15 and 5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So 15-5=10'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite, because it's -15... Can you do 5 - - 15?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What would that give you? You can also think about how far it is from -15 up to 0, and then up to 5.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-10'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hmm when we do 5 - - 15 that becomes 5 + 15, so 20. Does that make sense?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'It does. So the answer is 20. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep, the distance from the bottom of the rectangle (at -15) up to the top (at 5) is 20, and that's the height! question:
Question Text: What is the median of the following numbers? \( \frac{3}{7} , \quad \frac{5}{9} , \quad \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{3}{7} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{5}{9} \)
Answer D Text: There is no median
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi, would you still like any help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes please'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok great, so we're looking for the middle number when we put these fractions in order. Can you put them in order?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I cant figure out how to change th 2 into a multiple of 9 and 7'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ah ok we'll have to go for a pretty high common multiple! For just 9 and 7 we could use 63, but for 2 as well I think it will have to be 126"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Are you happy with changing all the fractions to be over 126?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'll try"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3/7 should be 54/7. 5/9 would be 70/63'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '54/126, but good work on the numerator :). For 3/7 I mean'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And same on the 5/9, it would be 70/126. Lastly 1/2?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '63/126'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent! So then we can put them in order based on the numerators'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '54/126 63/126 70/126. So the median is 63/126'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "There we go! And don't forget to put it back into the form it was in before"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent. Happy with how we got there?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done, bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: What is the mode of the following numbers? \( 0.4, \quad \frac{1}{4}, \quad 2.5, \quad \frac{2}{5} \)
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{4} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{2}{5} \)
Answer C Text: \( 0.4 \) and \( 2.5 \)
Answer D Text: There is no mode
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Leila!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hiiiii'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'do you know what a "mode" is?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so like ik what a mode is and how to work it out but. Fractions confuse me. Ye itâ€™s like the same numbers repeating and coming the most'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ok, so we need to make sure all of these are all fractions... or all decimals... so that we can be sure if a number is repeated or not. so, let's write them all as fractions... do you know how to write 0.4 as a fraction?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Er 4 over 10 ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great!! 4/10. and then, can we simplify that at all?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'lemme think this one through'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So divide it? For example. 2 divided by 5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes great! 4/10 = 2/5. ok, so our numbers are now... 2/5, 1/4, 2.5, 2/5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'how could you write 2.5 as a fraction?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 over 5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "no, that's 2 wholes and 0.5. 2.5 is 2 wholes plus 0.5"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Uh 1 over 4?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'not quite... 0.5 is the same as 5/10 or 1/2. so 2.5 is 2 and 1/2'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohh wait so there is no mode ? Sorry I donâ€™t get this'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'no worries....there is a mode... because you worked out that 0.4 = 2/5. so, 2/5 appears twice in that list'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohhh. tyyy chloeeeee'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No worries! ğŸ˜€. Well done! Bye for now ğŸ‘‹'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Byeee'}]

question:
Question Text: Which calculation would work out the range of this list of numbers? \( \frac{3}{7}, \quad \frac{5}{9}, \quad \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{2}-\frac{5}{9} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{5}{9}-\frac{1}{2} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{3}{7}-\frac{1}{2} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{5}{9}-\frac{3}{7} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Chiamaka!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so do you know how to find the range of a set of numbers in general?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'With the smallest and largest number'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep, we do the biggest minus the smallest. So we just need to work out which of these is biggest, and which is smallest, to work out what calculation we need. Now I can see one of the fractions is 1/2. I'd try comparing each of the others to 1/2. So, is 3/7 bigger or smaller than 1/2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Bigger'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can you explain how you decided that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Oh wsitno it's bigger. I man smaller"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes 3/7 is smaller than 1/2'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thank you bye. Oh sorry'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "we could see that if we wrote them both as fractions with the same denominator of 14, or we could just think about the fact that 3 is less than half of 7, so 3/7 must be less than 1/2. ok, so so far we know that 3/7 is smaller than 1/2. Now let's compare 1/2 and 5/9"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/2 is smaller'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's right. 5 is more than half of 9, so 5/9 is more than 1/2. Ok, so the order from smallest to biggest is 3/7, 1/2, 5/9. then for the range, we have to do biggest - smallest"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohok. Thank youbye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, bye Chiamaka!'}]

Question Text: Claire wants to draw a pie chart of the information.  Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?

Answer C Text: \( \frac{5}{24} \times 360 \)

Question Text: The bar chart shows the pets owned by pupils in a class.  What fraction of pupils own \( 3 \) pets?
Question Image: A bar chart showing the number of pets students own. 5 boys and 4 girls own 0 pets, 5 boys and 6 girls own 1 pet, 2 boys and 4 girls own 2 pets, 2 boys and 2 girls own 3 pets and 1 boy owns 4 pets.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{2}{31} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{2}{9} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{3}{4} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{4}{31} \)

question:
Question Text: What is the circumference of this circle in terms of \( \pi \) ?
Question Image: A circle with an 8 cm straight line drawn from one side to the other through the centre of the circle.
Answer A Text: \( 4 \pi\ \mathrm{cm} \)
Answer B Text: \( 8 \pi\ \mathrm{cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( 16 \pi\ \mathrm{cm} \)
Answer D Text: \( 64 \pi\ \mathrm{cm} \)

So what\'s the diameter here?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '16'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ooh close, that would be true if 8 was the radius, well done for applying that! question:
Question Text: Jack and Emma are arguing about which formula to use to calculate the area of a circle. Jack says you can use \( A=\pi r^{2} \) Emma says you can use \( A=\pi \frac{d^{2}}{2} \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Sabrina, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im not sure what this question means. r=d2. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'the radius is half of the diameter. so is diameter squared divided by 2 the same as radius squared?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hi Sabrina, I'm Claire :). I've just taken over as Lucy had a few other people that she was helping too :). Let's have a go at doing the diameter squared and dividing by 2 and see if that is the same. Let's say we have a circle with a diameter of 10cm. If we square that and divide by 2, what do we get? :)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Dividing by 2 gives us 5, and that would be the radius :). So what would the radius squared be? (That's 5 squared)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohhhh would it be 50 then?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Exactly, so that means dÂ²/2 is 50 :). What happens if we just do rÂ²?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2.5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So close! It's 25 :)"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohh so we divide 50 by 2 then?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes we would have to do that again, so the question was saying that dÂ²/2 is the same as rÂ². But actually we've found in this example that dÂ²/2 = 50, and rÂ² =25 and so we can see that they don't give us the same answer"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'would that mean emma is right then? jack i meant'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes it would! Well done ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks for your help may i leave now'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem at all! Absolutely, have a great day :D'}]

question:
Question Text: "Cube numbers have an odd number of factors"  Is this statement...
Answer A Text: always true
Answer B Text: sometimes true
Answer C Text: never true
Answer D Text: Impossible to say
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Catalina. how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont know what the answer would be to this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok no problem, lets have a think! so can you think of any cube numbers?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3x3x3 =27 so 27'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'brilliant! so lets think of what the factors of 27 are. (what numbers divide into 27 without leaving a remainder)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1,27     3,9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super! So it has 4 factors (and 4 is an even number). lets try another cube number... 8?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1,8      2,4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super, so again 4 factors, which is an even number. But maybe we need to think about a special cube number.. the number 1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "i@m not sure. i'm"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'well, the only number that goes into 1 is the number 1. so it only have one factor. so 1 has ONE factor (odd number of factors), 8 had 4 factors (odd number of factors), 27 has 4 factors (even number of factors). So the statement "Cube numbers have an off number of factors" is only SOMETIMES true'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so would it be sometimes true'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes indeed! Well done Catalina!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Does that make a little more sense now?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes indeed'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'super :) good luck with the rest of the lesson!'}]

question:
Question Text: How would you calculate the area of this triangle?
Question Image: A triangle, base 12m. All three sides are equal.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{6 \times 12}{2} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{12 \times 12}{2} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{12 \times 12 \times 12}{2} \)
Answer D Text: None of these

question:
Question Text: Which of the following numbers is a composite number?
Answer A Text: \( 11 \)
Answer B Text: \( 13 \)
Answer C Text: \( 15 \)
Answer D Text: None of these numbers are composite numbers

question:
Question Text: Jake is trying to solve this problem using Napier's bones What number does the circled digit represent?
Question Text: \( 356 \times 93 \)
Question Image: A Napier's bones grid, with 356 along the top and 93 down the side. From left to right on the top row, with / representing a diagonal line through through the box, the boxes read 2/7, 4/5, 5/4.  From left to right on the bottom row, the boxes read 0/9, 1/5, 1/8. The digit 5 is circled in the second box of the top row, which is in the column under the 5 of 356 and the row along from the 9 of 93.
Answer A Text: \( 5 \)
Answer B Text: \( 50 \)
Answer C Text: \( 500 \)
Answer D Text: \( 5000 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Elena! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Hi LilağŸ‘‹ I dont understand what the digit will be because I've never seen this method before."}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ah yes it's not as common as column multiplying ğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'lol'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "but it's the same ideas of place value, so let's see if we can make it clearer..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok :)'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Can you see which numbers were multiplied together to make the 45 in that square?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "yeah i actually looked at that part... it'd be 9x5"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great, and looking at where they are in the original question, can you see that that's actually 50 x 9?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh that makes senseğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '50x9 is 450'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Exactly!!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'and the 5 in 450 is 50 so it must be 50 right?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect, you got it!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yayğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab work Elena, you were really quick to pick that up ğŸ˜ğŸ§ '}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yay thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Happy to go back to the lesson?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yeah bye lila :0'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Bye! Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D

question:
Question Text: Miguel is recording the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right.  A new boy joins the class who has a cat and a dog.  Which box will change in value?
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline Number of pets & Frequency \\ \hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\ \hline \( 1 (A) \) & \( 6(B) \) \\ \hline \( 2(C) \) & \( 3(D) \) \\ \hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\ \hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D

question:
Question Text: Leo and Sophie are discussing how to work out \( 192 \div 8 \) Leo says you can do \( 192 \div 2 \div 2 \div 2 \) Sophie says you can do \( (192 \div 10)-(192 \div 2) \) Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Leo
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: \( 1 \mathrm{~km}=\square \mathrm{~mm} \)
Answer A Text: \( 100 \)
Answer B Text: \( 1000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 10000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1000000 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Lila, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hello i would like help with this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Of course, so we're looking at kilometres and millimetres, have you learned about them before?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, so can you fill this gap with any measurement you want? 1km = _________'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'but i still find it hard'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's fine, that's what I'm here for! I'll be more specific: how many metres are in a kilometre?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "isn't 1km =1000mm"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ah 1km is 1000m, which isn't quite the same"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'it isn,t ??? oh ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Can you picture a metre? It's about as long as your arms if you stretch them out. 1000 of those makes a kilometre. But 1mm is one millimetre, it's only as big as the tip of a pencil, so 1000 of those doesn't make a kilometre."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We know 1000 metres makes a kilometre, so we need to see how many millimetres is in 1000 metres'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '10000. 10,000'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite, but getting there. Do you know how many millimetres in 1 metre?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "yeah isn't it 1000"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Good, 1m = 1000mm. So 10m = ?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '10,000'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '100m = ?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '100,000'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And 1000m = ?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1,000,000'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. question:
Question Text: What is \( 242,395 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 ? \)
Answer A Text: \( 242,390 \)
Answer B Text: \( 242,000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 242,400 \)
Answer D Text: \( 240,000 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': "good morning! How can I help? oh I'm reading the question about rounding....."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes I donâ€™t really get how to round'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'would you like us to look at this together?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ye please'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'sure, lets look at this. focus on the last 3 numbers, the 395. which of those digits is in the tens column?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'no, the 3 is in the hundreds column'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Wait 9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes! the 9 is in the tens column. out of interest, which column is the 5 in?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'The 1â€™s'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ˜Š. lovely work! so, can you type the number 395 in words. ar you thinking?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Three hundred and ninety five'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "sorry typo! oh great, well done!! now let's think about rounding to the nearest 10. that means that instead of having the 95 part of the number we need to round off and have a 0 at the end instead of the 5. so when we round a number in the nineties to the nearest 10 it will either round up to 100 or it will round down to 90. if we had the number 92 is it nearer to 90 or to 100?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '90'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, and what about if we had the number 97? I mean, is 97 closer to 90 or to 100?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '100'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'perfect! so, what are your thoughts about 95?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Is it closer to 100?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "to be honest it's actually bang in the middle of 90 and 100, isn't it? so we have a special rule"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh ye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so, you seem ok with the idea that if we had 91,91,93,or 94 we would round down to 90 as they are all closer to 90 than to 100. and if the number was 96,97,98,99 then they would all round up to 100 as they are closer to 100 than to 90. but 95 is in the middle, the same distance away from 90 as from 100....... so the special rule is that we round UP when the number is a 5 or higher. is that familiar to you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes a bit'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'lovely, this lesson will give you some more practice. so, if we were asked to round 95 to the nearest 10 then our answer would be 100'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'in this question you are asked to round a much bigger number. but we are going to focus for a min on the 395 part first. so, we are going to need to round up the 95...... what do you think we will get if we round 395 to the nearest 10?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hmmmâ€¦ Iâ€™m not sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "lets think together. if it was just 95 we would go up to 100. so we are basically adding 5 on to round up to the 100. so let's do the same thing here. the answer cant be 100 as it's so much smaller than 395. but round up by adding 5"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Would it  be 1000'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'not quite. think about 395+5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '400'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, so if you round 395 to the nearest 10 the answer is 400. :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "llook at the question again, let's see if you can spot what the answer is... we were looking at 395 because it's the last 3 digits of the number in the qustion. 242,395. and we worked out that rounding 395 to the nearest 10 would be 400. there is no reason for the 242 part of the number to change. so can you spot what the right answer is?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ummmâ€¦â€¦. 242,400'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘ğŸ˜Š. well done! I know this is tricky at the momrnt for you. but with more practice you will soon feel more confident'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "so what I suggest is that when I leave and you can answer the question, even though you now know the right answer... I'd like you to click on the option that says something like 'yes but I'm not sure' and then you will get the option to watch videos explaining how to do the qustion. does taht make sense? and sorry for my  typos!!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes thanks you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "great! It's been lovely working with you. and please do watch the explanations on the videos in eedi, they are so helpful!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ok thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'feel free to ask for help again any timeğŸ˜Š'}]

so we have a special rule", 'student': 'Oh ye'}, {'turn': 11, 'teacher': 'so, you seem ok with the idea that if we had 91,91,93,or 94 we would round down to 90 as they are all closer to 90 than to 100. and if the number was 96,97,98,99 then they would all round up to 100 as they are closer to 100 than to 90. but 95 is in the middle, the same distance away from 90 as from 100....... so the special rule is that we round UP when the number is a 5 or higher. is that familiar to you?', 'student': 'Yes a bit'}, {'turn': 12, 'teacher': 'lovely, this lesson will give you some more practice. so, if we were asked to round 95 to the nearest 10 then our answer would be 100', 'student': 'Yes'}, {'turn': 13, 'teacher': 'in this question you are asked to round a much bigger number. but we are going to focus for a min on the 395 part first. so, we are going to need to round up the 95...... what do you think we will get if we round 395 to the nearest 10?', 'student': 'Hmmmâ€¦ Iâ€™m not sure'}, {'turn': 14, 'teacher': "lets think together. if it was just 95 we would go up to 100. so we are basically adding 5 on to round up to the 100. so let's do the same thing here. the answer cant be 100 as it's so much smaller than 395. but round up by adding 5", 'student': 'Would it  be 1000'}, {'turn': 15, 'teacher': 'not quite. think about 395+5', 'student': '400'}, {'turn': 16, 'teacher': 'yes, so if you round 395 to the nearest 10 the answer is 400. :)', 'student': 'Oh'}, {'turn': 17, 'teacher': "llook at the question again, let's see if you can spot what the answer is... we were looking at 395 because it's the last 3 digits of the number in the qustion. 242,395. and we worked out that rounding 395 to the nearest 10 would be 400. there is no reason for the 242 part of the number to change. so can you spot what the right answer is?", 'student': 'Ummmâ€¦â€¦. 242,400'}, {'turn': 18, 'teacher': 'ğŸ‘ğŸ˜Š. well done! I know this is tricky at the momrnt for you. but with more practice you will soon feel more confident', 'student': 'Ok thanks'}, {'turn': 19, 'teacher': "so what I suggest is that when I leave and you can answer the question, even though you now know the right answer... I'd like you to click on the option that says something like 'yes but I'm not sure' and then you will get the option to watch videos explaining how to do the qustion. does taht make sense? and sorry for my  typos!!", 'student': 'Yes thanks you'}, {'turn': 20, 'teacher': "great! It's been lovely working with you. and please do watch the explanations on the videos in eedi, they are so helpful!", 'student': 'Ok thank you'}, {'turn': 21, 'teacher': 'feel free to ask for help again any timeğŸ˜Š', 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: Which of these fractions could be placed between the fractions marked on the number line?
Question Image: A number line with 2/3 marked at one end, 9/12 at the other
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{9} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{3}{6} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{17}{24} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{5}{36} \)

question:
Question Text: Which of these fractions could be placed between the fractions marked on the number line?
Question Image: A number line with 2/3 marked at one end, 9/12 at the other
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{9} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{3}{6} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{17}{24} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{5}{36} \)
