question:
Question Text: By comparing the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded in each diagram, decide which is the odd one out?
Answer A Image: A rectangle with 1/3 shaded in red
Answer B Image: A rectangle with 2/6 shaded in blue
Answer C Image: A rectangle with 3/9 shaded in purple
Answer D Image: A rectangle with 6/12 shaded in orange
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'hi how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'How do I work the oud one out. Odd*'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'looks like you need to figure out what fraction each diagram represents'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Mhmmmmmm'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'look at A first. how many sections are red?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ˜ŠğŸ‘. and how many sections are there altogether'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3 so itâ€™s 1 out of 3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, perfect, that represents the fraction 1/3 ğŸ˜€. now what about B'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 out of 6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "great! Well done. so that is the fraction 2/6. let's take a moment to simplify 2/6. do you know how to do that?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Divide ? Idk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "yes, you're right. as 2 goes into both 2 and 6 we divide top and bottom by 2. if we do that, what do we get?   2/6=?/? we are just dividing each number by 2"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Uh3 bc 6 goes into 2 3 times'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, so the bottom number becomes 3. and the top number, 2, when we divide that by 2 we get 1. and so 2/6 simplifies to 1/3. they are the same size fraction'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So C is the odd one cuz you have to simplify it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "so A and B both have 1/3 of the shape coloured in. oh I haven't looked at C yet, lets do that now"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'how many are coloured in? and how many altogether?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3 out of 9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "great,, well done Leila! and so that shows the fraction 3/9. again let's take a moment to simplify that. what can we divide both 3 and 9 by?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Idk but I think the answer is 3. 3 6 9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "you're right! so what is 3 divide by 3"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, and what is 9 divide by 3?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "perfect! so that means that 3/9 simplifies to 1/3. so actually A, B and C all show the same fraction of coloured sections. that means it's probably D that is the odd one out, but let's look and see what fraction it's showing just to be sure"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Okayyyy'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'in D how many sections are coloured?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6 out of 12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ğŸ˜€. so that represents the fraction 6/12. let's simplify that. what is the biggest number that goes in to both 6 and 12?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'This is gunna take a bit of time so gimme a sec'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘. the options are 2, 3 and 6 tbh, those are the numbers that you can divide both 6 and 12 by. you ok?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Is it 72.. idk ğŸ˜­'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "oh I see what you've done, you've timesd 6 and 12 together. sorry that wasn't what I meant. I meant for you to think about what numbers you can divide 6 and 12 by. so the options are 2, 3, and 6 cos they all go in to both 6 and 12"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3? Iâ€™m so bad at dis ğŸ˜­'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "3 works! Let's divide both 6 and 12 by 3 (you're doing well, dont worry!). so, we have 6/12 and are going to divide top and bottom by 3. what is 6 divided by 3?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€. and what is 12 divide by 3?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Nd den 12 divide by 3 is 4?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes it is! and so now we have simplified 6/12 to 2/4. I think we can simplify 2/4 a bit more. what can we divide both 2 and 4 by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Uh 1? ğŸ˜­'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'almost!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'OHHHH 2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "YES YOU'RE RIGHT ğŸ†ğŸ˜. so we have 2/4. if we divide top and bottom by 2 what do we get?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1 over 2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, 1/2 ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yayy'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so in A, B and C 1/3 of the sections were coloured in. and in D 1/2 of the sections were coloured in. so D is definitely the odd one out!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So D is the odd 1. Thanksssssssss'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "yes. you're very welome Leila. I'll leave now so you can type in your answer and continue your lesson!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Okay byeeeeee Claire'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘‹ğŸ˜€ bye and enjoy the rest of your day!'}]

dialogue: [{'turn': 0, 'teacher': '', 'student': 'Hi'}, {'turn': 1, 'teacher': 'hi how can I help?', 'student': 'How do I work the oud one out. Odd*'}, {'turn': 2, 'teacher': 'looks like you need to figure out what fraction each diagram represents', 'student': 'Mhmmmmmm'}, {'turn': 3, 'teacher': 'look at A first. how many sections are red?', 'student': '1'}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': 'ğŸ˜ŠğŸ‘. and how many sections are there altogether', 'student': '3 so itâ€™s 1 out of 3'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': 'yes, perfect, that represents the fraction 1/3 ğŸ˜€. now what about B', 'student': '2 out of 6'}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': "great! Well done. so that is the fraction 2/6. let's take a moment to simplify 2/6. do you know how to do that?", 'student': 'Divide ? Idk'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': "yes, you're right. as 2 goes into both 2 and 6 we divide top and bottom by 2. if we do that, what do we get?   2/6=?/? we are just dividing each number by 2", 'student': 'Uh3 bc 6 goes into 2 3 times'}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': 'yes, so the bottom number becomes 3. and the top number, 2, when we divide that by 2 we get 1. and so 2/6 simplifies to 1/3. they are the same size fraction', 'student': 'So C is the odd one cuz you have to simplify it'}, {'turn': 9, 'teacher': "so A and B both have 1/3 of the shape coloured in. oh I haven't looked at C yet, lets do that now", 'student': 'Oh okay'}, {'turn': 10, 'teacher': 'how many are coloured in? and how many altogether?', 'student': '3 out of 9'}, {'turn': 11, 'teacher': "great,, well done Leila! and so that shows the fraction 3/9. again let's take a moment to simplify that. what can we divide both 3 and 9 by?", 'student': 'Idk but I think the answer is 3. 3 6 9'}, {'turn': 12, 'teacher': "you're right! so what is 3 divide by 3", 'student': '1'}, {'turn': 13, 'teacher': 'yes, and what is 9 divide by 3?', 'student': '3'}, {'turn': 14, 'teacher': "perfect! so that means that 3/9 simplifies to 1/3. so actually A, B and C all show the same fraction of coloured sections. that means it's probably D that is the odd one out, but let's look and see what fraction it's showing just to be sure", 'student': 'Okayyyy'}, {'turn': 15, 'teacher': 'in D how many sections are coloured?', 'student': '6 out of 12'}, {'turn': 16, 'teacher': "ğŸ˜€. so that represents the fraction 6/12. let's simplify that. what is the biggest number that goes in to both 6 and 12?", 'student': 'This is gunna take a bit of time so gimme a sec'}, {'turn': 17, 'teacher': 'ğŸ‘. the options are 2, 3 and 6 tbh, those are the numbers that you can divide both 6 and 12 by. you ok?', 'student': 'Is it 72.. idk ğŸ˜­'}, {'turn': 18, 'teacher': "oh I see what you've done, you've timesd 6 and 12 together. sorry that wasn't what I meant. I meant for you to think about what numbers you can divide 6 and 12 by. so the options are 2, 3, and 6 cos they all go in to both 6 and 12", 'student': '3? Iâ€™m so bad at dis ğŸ˜­'}, {'turn': 19, 'teacher': "3 works! Let's divide both 6 and 12 by 3 (you're doing well, dont worry!). so, we have 6/12 and are going to divide top and bottom by 3. what is 6 divided by 3?", 'student': '2'}, {'turn': 20, 'teacher': 'ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€. and what is 12 divide by 3?', 'student': 'Nd den 12 divide by 3 is 4?'}, {'turn': 21, 'teacher': 'yes it is! and so now we have simplified 6/12 to 2/4. I think we can simplify 2/4 a bit more. what can we divide both 2 and 4 by?', 'student': 'Uh 1? ğŸ˜­'}, {'turn': 22, 'teacher': 'almost!', 'student': 'OHHHH 2'}, {'turn': 23, 'teacher': "YES YOU'RE RIGHT ğŸ†ğŸ˜. so we have 2/4. if we divide top and bottom by 2 what do we get?", 'student': '1 over 2'}, {'turn': 24, 'teacher': 'yes, 1/2 ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€', 'student': 'yayy'}, {'turn': 25, 'teacher': 'so in A, B and C 1/3 of the sections were coloured in. and in D 1/2 of the sections were coloured in. so D is definitely the odd one out!', 'student': 'So D is the odd 1. Thanksssssssss'}, {'turn': 26, 'teacher': "yes. you're very welome Leila. I'll leave now so you can type in your answer and continue your lesson!", 'student': 'Okay byeeeeee Claire'}, {'turn': 27, 'teacher': 'ğŸ‘‹ğŸ˜€ bye and enjoy the rest of your day!', 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: By comparing the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded in each diagram, decide which is the odd one out?
Answer A Image: A rectangle with 1/3 shaded in red
Answer B Image: A rectangle with 2/6 shaded in blue
Answer C Image: A rectangle with 3/9 shaded in purple
Answer D Image: A rectangle with 6/12 shaded in orange
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there ğŸ‘‹ how can I help you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I need help. With knowing how to find whicjh one is odd. Have you disconnected. Bye'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'sorry I am here! Was just helping another student'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohh Ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You need to find out what fraction of each rectangle is shaded in its simplest form. there is one that is not the same'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "is it 3 ( C ). Are you helping a student. Miss , what happened. â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“â“. Hello. Miss I need help. Ok bye. LOL Miss where are you. I need helppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppppp. I'm leaving then"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Found you! Sorry it said you went offline so the chat disappeared. For A, how much is shaded?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Ohh sorry for the rude comments'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It's fine, so how much is shaded in A?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1 third'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'okay good, and how about in B?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 sixes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '2/6 simplifies to what?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1 third'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'okay and how about c?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3 nines'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '3/9 simplifies to what?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'And is the same as 1 third , so the answer is D  wooo hooo'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes! well done. do you need any more help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Mabye on the next but I am doing a bit beter. better'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "okay good. Give it a go! I'll let you get back to the lesson"}]

question:
Question Text: Which of these options show the numbers \[ 8,605,527 \quad 8,605,572 \quad 8,650,527 \quad 8,605,752 \] in order from smallest to largest?
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{l}8,650,527 \\ 8,605,752 \\ 8,605,572 \\ 8,605,527\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{l}8,605,752 \\ 8,605,572 \\ 8,650,527 \\ 8,605,527\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{l}8,605,527 \\ 8,605,752 \\ 8,605,572 \\ 8,650,527\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( \begin{array}{l}8,605,527 \\ 8,605,572 \\ 8,605,752 \\ 8,650,527\end{array} \)

question:
Question Text: What temperature does the thermometer show?
Question Image: A thermometer showing the temperature in degrees Celsius. There are five steps on the scale between 10 and 0, and five steps between 0 and -10. The temperature is shown at 2 steps below 0.
Answer A Text: \( -2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer B Text: \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer C Text: \( -4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer D Text: \( -13^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

question:
Question Text: \( a \) and \( b \) are integers between \( 0 \) and \( 5 \). \[ 2 a-b=6 \] How many different possible values of \( a \) are there that satisfy the equation?
Answer A Text: \( 6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 5 \)
Answer C Text: \( 4 \)
Answer D Text: \( 3 \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'i9m stuckl. im stuck'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "yeah this looks tricky , let's look at it together. it says that a and b are integers, what does that mean?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'whole value. positive#'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, def whole value'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'answer is d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'and in this case they are positive because it says they are between 0 and 5. but usually integers could be positive or negative.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'we have got positive options'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "OK, so now let's put in different numbers in place of b and see if we can work out what a needs to be. so, if we put in b=0 we would get 2a-0=6. what is a when b=0?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'check, we have 2a-0=6. so 2a=6. so what is a?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'no, 2xa is 6. so you need to do 6/2 to get a'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, if b=0 then a=3. is that ok?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yeas. so it is d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "so that's one. now, let's change b so that now b=1. the equation is 2a-b=6. so now we need to solve 2a-1=6"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'sorry I just spotted your quetsion. a=3 is just one answer that we have found at the momrnt, we need to see if we can find more. 2a-1=6. have you done any solving equations? in school I mean'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great, so how could you solve 2a-1=6? what would a good first step be?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'work out a. is a 4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "nearly, not quite. as 2x4-1 wouldn't equal 6"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'a is 3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "this is a tricky one, a isn't a whole number this time. as 2x3-1 isn't 6 either. let me talk through solving 2a-1=6"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'there is no other option'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'first thing that would be good to do is to add one to each side. that would give us 2a=7'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'can i return back to the lesson'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'oh, OK. feel free to request help again any time!'}]

question:

Answer A Text: \( \frac{5}{9} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{3}{12} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{3}{9} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{6} \)

question:
Question Text: Work out: \[ 0.4 \times 15 \]
Answer A Text: \( 0.6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 6 \)
Answer C Text: \( 7 \)
Answer D Text: \( 60 \)

question:
Question Text: What fraction replaces the question mark?
Question Image: Bar model split into 4 equal pieces. One of these pieces is coloured green and is divided into two pieces with one part labelled with a question mark
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{5} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{2}{5} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{1}{8} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{4} \)

question:
Question Text: Which calculation gives the fraction that replaces the question mark?
Question Image: A horizontal bar divided into 4 equal sections with vertical lines. The left hand section of these is coloured green and is further divided into 2 equal sections with vertical dotted lines. A curly bracket shows that the width of one of these green sections is denoted by a question mark.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{2}{5} \times \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{1}{4} \div \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{2}{5} \div 2 \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{4} \times \frac{1}{2} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Lila!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'oh, would you like us to work on this question together?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes please! :)'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great! what fraction is the green section?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/4?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes it is :). and can you see that the diagram is trying to find half of it?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so, lets think for a min about how we find half of something.....'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'divide by two?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "so, if I want to find half of the number 10, I usually divide by 2 to get 5. but there isn't an option to divide 1/4 bt 2. hahaha you were faster than me! so, what can we multiply by that gives us the same answer as dividing by 2?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '50?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'not quite :). think about 10 divide by 2'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'we know the answer is 5. can you think what we can multiply 10 by and still get the answer 5?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '(sorry, I typed "we know..." bfore I saw your answer 5!! byt 10x2 isn\'t 5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im not sure sorry'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "that's ok. we can say we have o find half of 10 instead of doing 10/2, can't we? and so to find half of 10 we do 10 x1/2. so, what I'm trying to show is that timesing by 1/2 is the same as dividing by 2"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ooooh ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "so, 10 x1/2=5. and 10/2=5. let's look again at this question. we have 1/4"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "are finding half of it. we would quite like to do 1/4 divided by 2. but that isn't one of the options. can you see which option is still going to give us the right answer?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'would it be 1/4 divided by 1/2? im not that good at maths ğŸ˜…'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "not quite, as we want to divide by 2 and dividing by 1/2 can't give us the same answer as dividing by 2. remember in my example we said 10/2=5 and also 10x1/2=5. (you are working hard at your Maths and that will help you get better and better!! Maths is just about working and practising, and that is what you are doing today). have another look at the options"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/4x1/2?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ˜€ğŸ‘. yes, that is the right one!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thank you :D'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you know hwat you get if you do that calcualtion? sorry typos!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1/8?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes!!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': ':D'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "and if you look at the diagram, half of the green section would indeed be 1/8ğŸ˜€. it's been lovely working with you Lila"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thank you!ğŸ˜'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'll leave now and you will get  achance to write the answer"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok!'}]

question:
Question Text: Round \( 7.503 \) to the nearest whole number
Answer A Text: \( 6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 7 \)

question:
Question Text: Which of the following is the correct way of writing:
Question Text: \( p \) divided by \( q \), then add \( 3 \)
Question Text: using algebraic convention?
Answer A Text: \( p q+3 \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{p}{q}+3 \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{p}{q+3} \)
Answer D Text: \( p-q+3 \)

question:
Question Text: Which of the following fractions is equivalent to \( \frac{8}{12} \) ?
Answer A Text: \( \frac{3}{4} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{10}{14} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{10}{15} \)
Answer D Text: None of these

question:
Question Text: How many rectangles would you need to shade so that \( 80 \% \) of this shape is shaded?
Question Image: Rectangle split into 20 equal parts
Answer A Text: \( 18 \)
Answer B Text: \( 16 \)
Answer C Text: \( 8 \)
Answer D Text: \( 4 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there Abdul! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi samantha. I need help on stage 5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok no problem! Let me check it for you :). Ok so firstly, do you know that the percentage symbol means per 100? :). so 80% means 80/100'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yeah. Mhm'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super! So think of this as a fraction: 80/100. But in this question, we have 20 rectangles. So we need to think of our fraction out of 20, NOT out of 100'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Would you simplify it?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'YES! super! So we are going to simplify it a little, so that the bottom number of the fraction (the denominator) is 20. any thoughts how we can go from 100 to 20? What should we divide by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Would you do 100Ã·5?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'brilliant! well done :). and we must do the same to the top number (the numerator) - it also must be divided by 5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Its 16!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes brilliant, so 16 out of 20 :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'If you did 80Ã·5 that would be16!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'brilliant work!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thank you samantha'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'is that a little clearer now?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes, I would like to go back to the question!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem at all, good luck with the rest of the lesson! :)'}]

question:
Question Text: These two shapes are similar (not drawn to scale). What should replace the star?
Question Image: Two scalene triangles. The bigger one has sides 9 cm and 7.5 cm. On the smaller triangle, the side corresponding to the 9 cm is 6 cm, and the side corresponding to the 7.5 cm is marked with a star.
Answer A Text: \( 3.75 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer B Text: \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( 4.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer D Text: Not enough information

question:
Question Text: Amelia is organising a charity hot dog sale. There are \( 18 \) bread rolls in each packet. There are \( 15 \) hot dogs in each packet. Amelia buys exactly the same number of bread rolls as hot dogs. What is the smallest number of each packet that Amelia can buy?  To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 18 \) and \( 15 \)

Answer B Text: Sum
Answer C Text: Lowest Common Multiple
Answer D Text: Highest Common Factor

question:
Question Text: Nina wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.  \[ 87.4 \times 0.3727 \]  What number should replace \( \mathbf{8 7 . 4} \) in her estimation?
Answer A Text: \( 90 \)
Answer B Text: \( 87 \)
Answer C Text: \( 88 \)
Answer D Text: \( 80 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Elara! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im a bit stuck on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem let's look at it together. Have you learned about significant figures before?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes but only in primary school ages ago'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok so a reminder: significant figures can be any place value, but they are the "important digits" in a number, so anything that\'s not a zero at the beginning. In the number 87.4 we have three significant figures, the 8 7 and 4. So if we\'re rounding to one significant figure we look at the first one of those, which is the 8. Then we can think about place value. What\'s the value of the 8 in this number? (for example is it 8 hundreds, 8 tens, 8 ones...)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '8 tens'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Perfect, so we're rounding to the nearest ten! Does that make sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent, Can you round 87,4 to the nearest 10?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '87'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite, that's the nearest 1. Remember if we are rounding to the nearest 10 we count in tens, so it will be 80 or 90"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh. 90'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's it ğŸ‘. So to recap we looked at the first number, found it's place value, then rounded to that value, giving us 90. Happy to go on with that? Or would you like another example?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i think im ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Brill, keep up the good work!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'acctually #'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i might do another example'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, what about... Round 36.8 to one significant figure'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '37'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'One more try... Think about what place value you are rounding to'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '? i dont know'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'The first significant figure is the 3, is that 3 hundreds 3 tens or 3 ones?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'tens'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Good, so we're rounding to the nearest ten again"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '40'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yeah!!! ğŸ¤©ğŸ‰'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohhh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '36.4 to one significant figure is 40'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Did that one make a bit more sense?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thankyou'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're welcome! dialogue: [{'turn': 1, 'teacher': 'Hi Elara! How can I help?', 'student': 'im a bit stuck on this question'}, {'turn': 2, 'teacher': "No problem let's look at it together. Have you learned about significant figures before?", 'student': 'yes but only in primary school ages ago'}, {'turn': 3, 'teacher': 'Ok so a reminder: significant figures can be any place value, but they are the "important digits" in a number, so anything that\'s not a zero at the beginning. In the number 87.4 we have three significant figures, the 8 7 and 4. So if we\'re rounding to one significant figure we look at the first one of those, which is the 8. Then we can think about place value. What\'s the value of the 8 in this number? (for example is it 8 hundreds, 8 tens, 8 ones...)', 'student': '8 tens'}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': "Perfect, so we're rounding to the nearest ten! Does that make sense?", 'student': 'yes'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': 'Excellent, Can you round 87,4 to the nearest 10?', 'student': '87'}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': "Not quite, that's the nearest 1. Remember if we are rounding to the nearest 10 we count in tens, so it will be 80 or 90", 'student': 'oh. 90'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': "That's it ğŸ‘. So to recap we looked at the first number, found it's place value, then rounded to that value, giving us 90. Happy to go on with that? Or would you like another example?", 'student': 'i think im ok'}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': 'Brill, keep up the good work!', 'student': 'acctually #'}, {'turn': 9, 'teacher': 'Yes?', 'student': 'i might do another example'}, {'turn': 10, 'teacher': 'Great, what about... Round 36.8 to one significant figure', 'student': '37'}, {'turn': 11, 'teacher': 'One more try... Think about what place value you are rounding to', 'student': '? i dont know'}, {'turn': 12, 'teacher': 'The first significant figure is the 3, is that 3 hundreds 3 tens or 3 ones?', 'student': 'tens'}, {'turn': 13, 'teacher': "Good, so we're rounding to the nearest ten again", 'student': '40'}, {'turn': 14, 'teacher': 'Yeah!!! ğŸ¤©ğŸ‰', 'student': 'ohhh'}, {'turn': 15, 'teacher': '36.4 to one significant figure is 40', 'student': 'yes'}, {'turn': 16, 'teacher': 'Did that one make a bit more sense?', 'student': 'yes'}, {'turn': 17, 'teacher': 'Fab!', 'student': 'thankyou'}, {'turn': 18, 'teacher': "You're welcome! Happy to go one with the lesson now? *go on", 'student': 'yes'}, {'turn': 19, 'teacher': 'Bye! ğŸ‘‹ğŸ˜Š', 'student': 'bye'}]

question:

Answer B Text: \( 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 13 \)
Answer D Text: \( 4 \)

question:
Question Text: \( 2 \frac{2}{3} \div 2 \) Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
Answer A Text: \( 1 \frac{1}{3} \)
Answer B Text: \( 1 \frac{2}{3} \)
Answer C Text: \( 2 \frac{1}{3} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{3}{4} \)

question:
Question Text: What is the next term of this linear sequence? \[ 7,11,15,19, \ldots \]
Answer A Text: \( 20 \)
Answer B Text: \( 21 \)

Question Text: Lisa says these two rectangles are similar
Question Image: Two rectangles of different sizes. One rectangle has width 4cm and height 6cm. The other rectangle has width 8cm and height 10cm.
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Lisa
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Lisa
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: Jack and Emma are discussing quadratic sequences.  Jack says this is a quadratic sequence: \( 24,15,8,3,0 \ldots \)  Emma says this is a quadratic sequence: \( 124,63,26,7,3,0, \ldots \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Farhan! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hello I need help with this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's have a look... So, first of all, do you know what a quadratic sequence is?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think it is where a sequence is added by the same amount'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, it's where the second difference is the same amount each time...."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yeah i think'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, what that means is.... This would be quadratic.... 2,5,10,17.... What's the difference between each number?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Did you jump straight to the second difference? If so, great, well done! And a linear sequence is one like this.... 2,5,8,11....   adding the same amount each time.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! Ok, let's look at the question you're doing... 24, 15, 8, 3, 0... This is Jack's sequence. What's the second difference here?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'that might be a quadratic'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes....why?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Because the difference between 24 and 15 is 9 and the difference between 15 and 8 and 3 is 6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, the differences are 9,7,5,3. And the differences between each of those numbers is always 2. Great! Ok, what about Emma's?  124, 63, 26, 7, 3, 0..."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I don't think it is a quadratic"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Nor do I....why do you think that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Aas it doesn't follow the rules of a quadratic. as"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, that's right....the differences are something like 61, 35, 19, 4, 3...... So, it's only quadratic if the difference between each of those numbers is the same...."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so that means jack is correct'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! ğŸ˜€. Great work! I'll leave you to enter your answer. ğŸ™‚"}]

question:
Question Text: Which inequality is represented by the diagram?
Question Image: A number line with a hollow circle above -1with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers -2, -3, -4, -5 etc
Answer A Text: \( x<-1 \)
Answer B Text: \( x \leq-1 \)
Answer C Text: \( x>-1 \)
Answer D Text: \( x \geq-1 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Liana :). How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i forgot how you do inequalities'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem! Let's take a look. So what number is the circle over?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-1'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! And what direction is the arrow pointing?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'left'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! Is it pointing towards numbers that are less than -1 or greater than -1?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'less than'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Super! So we know that x is LESS THAN -1. Now that means we could write x<-1 or x<=-1. What's the difference between the inequality symbol with the single arrow and the one with the extra line?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'idk but i know how to do it now'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok. Because the circle above the -1 is not coloured in, it means that we don't actually include the -1. So we have to write x<-1. If the circle was coloured in it would mean we could include the -1 so it would mean that 'x is less than OR EQUAL to -1'"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! Are you happy to return to the quiz?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super, well done today ğŸ”¥'}]

question:
Question Text: Jack and Emma are discussing calculations involving square roots.  Jack says \( \sqrt{16}+\sqrt{9}=7 \)  Emma says \( \sqrt{16+9}=7 \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Lila, thank you for your patience, we have a few students online. Can you please watch the video while I read the question :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Have you watched it :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'what is root (16) and Root (9)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '16)4 9)3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent and what do they add to give'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'What'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So sqrt(16)+sqrt(9). if we know that is 4+3'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25. 7'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '7 super so we know Jack is correct. What do we think about Emma'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Nope'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Why? :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I mean they are both correct'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Well sqrt (16+9), we need to do 16+9 first then square root. Can you do that for me Emma. **Lila , can you do Emma's calculation"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '16+9=25'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Amazing and what is square root of 25'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '4+3=7. 5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Amazing, so emma's answer is 5 not 7. So only Jack is correct"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yep'}]

question:
Question Text: Oscar is playing a game where all \( 26 \) letters of the alphabet at placed into a bag and Oscar has to pick one out at random. Picking a \( \mathrm{P} \) and a vowel are known as...
Answer A Text: Independent events
Answer B Text: Mutually exclusive events
Answer C Text: Probability events
Answer D Text: Dependant events
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again Sophie!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi again'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Is it possible to pick out a letter and have it be both a P AND a vowel?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'umm. i dont know'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Is P a vowel?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I agree. So if Oscar has picked out a P, they haven't picked out a vowel."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "If they've picked a vowel, they can't have picked the letter P. Those two things can't happen at the same time."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so is it a'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Events that can't happen at the same time are called 'mutually exclusive'."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh. so ts b. it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It is. Shall I pass you back so you can tell Eedi?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes pls'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Will do!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'please'}]

question:
Question Text: A vegetarian restaurant wants to know people's eating habits \( 50 \) people in Town \( A \) are asked if they eat meat.
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town A } \\ \hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\ \hline Yes & \( 39 \) \\ \hline No & \( 11 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Question Text: \( 200 \) people in Town B are asked if they eat meat.
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|cc|} \hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town B } \\ \hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\ \hline Yes & \( 143 \) \\ \hline No & \( 57 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Question Text: Which results are more reliable?
Answer A Text: Town A
Answer B Text: Town B
Answer C Text: They are the same
Answer D Text: Impossible to say

Do you know what we mean by reliability?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'which is the one you can work whith the most. is it impossible to say because they are both reliable. you can use them both'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes! I would agree'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay can i exit. bbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbb'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So reliability is when you repeat the experiment and get the same results each time'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so the answer is d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well how many times have you done each experiment?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1s'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Exactly so I think because you have done them both once, they have equal reliability. Before you go, do you know what validity means?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it right. i wrote c but is said it is wrong. and you said the reliability is equal. that doesnt make sense'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "OK so I've just re-read the question"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'what letter did i click'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It's always important to slow down and make sure you take everything in, I have a feeling you might rush things sometime as you're so rapid on this chat ğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "If you read the teacher feedback it is stating that each time a person is asked it's classing that as 1 run of the experiment... So which of the two surveys asks the most people?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'town b. meaning that is most reliable'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Exactly so that one would be the most reliable'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Perfect, I'll hand you back to Eedi now!"}]

question:
Question Text: A biased dice is rolled \( 40 \) times.  \( 19 \) sixes are recorded.  Which of the following is the best guess for the number of sixes you would get if you rolled the dice \( 1000 \) times?
Answer A Text: \( 167 \)
Answer B Text: \( 475 \)
Answer C Text: \( 19 \)
Answer D Text: \( 25 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Mira! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'sup. hehe can u help me with thius'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Sure! So we've got to think about proportion here"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '19 sixes were recorded, out of how many rolls?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '40#'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Super. So how could we write that as a fraction?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '19/40'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! Now we need to estimate how many times we'd get a 6 if we rolled it 1000 times. We'll need to use equivalent fractions here. Which number do we want to change to 1000, the numerator or denominator?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '475'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'oo, can you tell me why you think 475?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'idk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's ok, we're nearly there, let's just continue with our fractions. So we have 19/40 and we want to know how many we would get out of 1000"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it right ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So we want to turn the denominator from 40 into 1000. Any idea what we'd have to multiply it by?"}]

question:
Question Text: A biased dice is rolled \( 40 \) times.  \( 19 \) sixes are recorded.  Which of the following is the best guess for the number of sixes you would get if you rolled the dice \( 1000 \) times?
Answer A Text: \( 167 \)
Answer B Text: \( 475 \)
Answer C Text: \( 19 \)
Answer D Text: \( 25 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I don't get it. Can you explain it"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok, when the dice was rolled first, 19/40 rolls were sixes. Ok with that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yep]'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So we say the probability of rolling 6 on this dice is 19/40'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'That means in 1000 rolls, 19/40 of those rolls should be 6. Can you find 19/40 of 1000?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, to find a fraction of an amount we divide by the denominator to find 1/40, then multiply by the numerator to get 19/40. So first, 1000 divided by 40. Can you divide it by 10 and then 4, to make it easier?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So close!! That would be dividing by 400'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no that was 10 divided by 4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ah sorry I meant 1000 divided by 10, and then divide your answer by 4'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done ğŸ˜ 1/40 of 1000 is 25.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'do D?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Now we want 19/40, so 25 x 19'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'B. Can I get 100 coins?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent :D Of course! Bye!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}]

question:
Question Text: Emma and Nolan share some yoghurt in the ratio \( 2: 3 \). Emma has \(_____\) of the total yoghurt What fraction completes the sentence?
Answer A Text: \( \frac{2}{3} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{2}{5} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{1}{5} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there Tessa how are you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'could be better but ok how are you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ahh let's hope I can help you out here. I'm good, thank you. do you need some help with this question?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes i am a bit stuck and dont understand what to do'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ok, I can see from your first try you selected A, which means you have been able to identify how many parts Emma has. How many parts does Emma have?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "super. now let's look at how this be given as a fraction of the total parts. the total yoghurt is shared into 2:3 parts"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'when writing a fraction, the denominator (bottom) represents the total parts. how many is that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "ok, let's go back to the ratio. Emma and Nolan share a yoghurt. you told me Emma gets 2 parts of the yoghurt. how many parts does Nolan get?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, super!! So how many parts have been shared altogether?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'excellent. that is the total number of parts we use for our fraction. so get gets 2 parts out of 5'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so it is b'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "that's it Tessa!! well done. would you be able to tell the the fraction Nolan gets?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3\\5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'fantastic - so altogether, 2/5 + 3/5 = 5/5 (which is the complete yoghurt). How do you feel about this question now?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i feel great'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'glad to hear it. can I help you with anything else?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no you have been a great help lila thank you so much'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "you're welcome Tessa - keep up the great work ğŸ‰ğŸ˜Š. I'll send you back to the lesson now"}]

Emma and Nolan share a yoghurt. you told me Emma gets 2 parts of the yoghurt. how many parts does Nolan get?", 'student': '3'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': 'yes, super!! So how many parts have been shared altogether?', 'student': '5'}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': 'excellent. that is the total number of parts we use for our fraction. so get gets 2 parts out of 5', 'student': 'so it is b'}, {'turn': 9, 'teacher': "that's it Tessa!! well done. would you be able to tell the the fraction Nolan gets?", 'student': '3\\5'}, {'turn': 10, 'teacher': 'fantastic - so altogether, 2/5 + 3/5 = 5/5 (which is the complete yoghurt). How do you feel about this question now?', 'student': 'i feel great'}, {'turn': 11, 'teacher': 'glad to hear it. can I help you with anything else?', 'student': 'no you have been a great help lila thank you so much'}, {'turn': 12, 'teacher': "you're welcome Tessa - keep up the great work ğŸ‰ğŸ˜Š. I'll send you back to the lesson now", 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: \( 50 \) has been increased by \( n \% \) and the final answer is \( 65 \). What is the value of \( n \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 3 \)
Answer B Text: \( 1500 \)
Answer C Text: \( 15 \)
Answer D Text: \( 30 \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'Hi again!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! Ooh a reverse percentage question, any ideas on this one?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i know it cant be 15 beacuse that would just be adding nt finding the percentage'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ah but that is the right first step! Then we need to decide what 15 is as a percentage of 50. We can do that by writing it as a fraction, 15/50, then can you think how to get a percentage?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'write it into a decimal and times by 100'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! Can you change 15/50 into a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'divide the top by the bottom?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep you could do that, but there's an easier way for this one... Can you convert the fraction to have 100 on the bottom?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yep'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What would that give you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15/100'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Remember if we double the bottom we need to double the top too!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '30/100'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Good, 15/50 = 30/100 ğŸ˜. And then what's 30/100 as a decimal/percentage?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '30%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great, that's your answer!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay! thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We found the increase, then changed it into a percentage of the original amount :). Good to go?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yep!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab, bye!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: Leo and Lisa are discussing how to solve: \(  \frac{3 x}{2} + 1 =5  \)  Leo says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{3 x}{2}=4 \)  Lisa says a correct next line of working could be: \( 3 x+1=10 \)  Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Leo
Answer B Text: Only Lisa
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Lisa
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

What's changed your mind? What did it become in Leo's equation?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '4. i think i got it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What are you thinking?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'its d. bcsssss. lisa didnt do it right either'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Not quite - Leo is correct. question:
Question Text: Seamus decides to add these two equations together.
Question Text: \( \begin{array}{r}3 x+2 y=9 \\ x-2 y=5\end{array} \)
Question Text: What should his next line of working be?
Answer A Text: \( 4 x=14 \)
Answer B Text: \( 4 x-4 y=14 \)
Answer C Text: \( 4 x+4 y=14 \)
Answer D Text: \( 2 x=14 \)

question:
Question Text: Which of the following statements can you prove from this diagram?
Question Image: Angles around a point split into three parts labelled with: m+100, 2m-n and 260-2m
Answer A Text: \( m=n \)
Answer B Text: \( m+n=90 \)
Answer C Text: \( m+n=180 \)
Answer D Text: \( m+n=360 \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! Sophia here ğŸ˜ƒ Have you had any thoughts or done any working for this question so far? ğŸ¤”ğŸ¤”ğŸ¤”'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Just give me a minute to take a look at the question and we'll do it together ğŸ‘. So those angles are making a full circle. So what do they add up to?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '360ğŸ˜‡'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'AMAZING so m + 100 + 2m - n + 260 - 2m = 360. Can you collect any like terms there?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes. would it be A?ğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜‡'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Why A?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i am actually not too sure it was just a random guessğŸ™‚ğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜‡'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'so m + 100 + 2m - n + 260 - 2m = 360. So if we look at the ms. we have m + 2m - 2m. what is that?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'm or 1m'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great. and the numbers? 100 + 260?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '360'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So that bit before the = gives us m - n + 360. m - n + 360 = 360. What would happen if we took 360 away from both sides? If we took 360 away from both sides they would disappear leaving us with m - n = 0. Which you're correct, does become A"}]

question:
Question Text: Simplify this expression \( \frac{12 c+18}{6} \)
Answer A Text: \( 12 c+3 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 c+3 \)
Answer C Text: \( 72 c+108 \)
Answer D Text: \( 5 c \)

question:
Question Text: What should replace the star and triangle when this expression is fully factorised?
Question Text: \( 3 a^{2}+2 a \equiv {\bigstar}(\triangle a-\bigcirc) \)
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=3 \\ \Delta=a\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=3 \\ \Delta=2\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=a \\ \Delta=3\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=2 \\ \Delta=3\end{array} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there Sophia!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I just don't understand how to work it out"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok lets have a look together!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Have you studied factorising an expression before?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Brilliant! so we need to take out the highest common factor. what would be common in both 3a^2 and 2a'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6 ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hmm.. I dont think 6 goes into both of those terms! Can you see how they both have an a in them?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So I think we should take the a out of the bracket! so now we have a( ____ + __)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes. would the triangle be 3'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It would indeed :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'because a + 3 is 3a. or is it times'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'it is times :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ahh yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'but yes, a times 3 is 3a!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yay. so the answer is c thne. then'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So the star would be a, and the triangle 3 :). Yes, C, brilliant Sophia!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Is there anything else I can help with? :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think I understand now'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Enjoy the rest of your lesson!'}]

Answer C Text: \( 1\;: 3 \)

Answer B Text: \( 7 \)

turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Nina! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I donâ€™t understand how I got it wrong'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Did you start by making the mixed numbers into improper fractions, or did you go straight to multiplying?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Iâ€™m not sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'When we have a multiplication like this, where there are whole numbers and fractions, we want to start by making everything into fractions. Then we can multiply straight across. So first can you change 1 1/2 into ___/2?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Wait is the answer b'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Just had to double check, but no not quite'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh sorry'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem! Well done for having another go :D. If we make 1 1/2 into an improper fraction, we do 1 x 2 and + the extra 1, so 3/2. Have you done that method before?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great, can you try the same thing with 3 2/3? 3x3 =9, and + the extra 2 gives us 11, so 11/3. Is that ok up to there? Stop me if I'm going too fast"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So that means our multiplication is 3/2 x 11/3. And when we multiply fractions we just multiply the numerators for the top, and multiply the denominators for the bottom, so what does that give us?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '33/6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect, and can you change that back into a mixed number to find out what the missing number in the question is?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Iâ€™m not sure'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Try 33 Ã· 6, and put the remainder as the fraction part (over 6) ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3/6??'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's the remainder part, exactly! And what did you get for the whole number before that?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I donâ€™t know'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How many whole 6s in 33?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done ğŸ˜ We do 33Ã·6 = 5 remainder 3, and that tells us that 33/6 = 5 3/6'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So itâ€™s d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep that's it, well done that was a lot of work!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Feeling ready to go on?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fab, bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: What does the following equal?  \( 3-5 \times 4+2 \)
Answer A Text: \( -19 \)
Answer B Text: \( -27 \)
Answer C Text: \( -15 \)
Answer D Text: \( -6 \)

question:
Question Text: Liam and Emma are discussing the order of operations Liam says: \( 3+2-1 \equiv 3-1+2 \) Emma says: \( 3+2 \times 1 \equiv 2 \times 1+3 \)
Answer A Text: Only Liam
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Liam and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Why r there 3 lines instead of equal signs?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'That\'s an identity sign, it still means that the two sides are equal but it\'s just a stronger way of saying "these things are identical to each other". So you can still think of the question as if they were normal equals signs'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I don't see the point in that sign it literally just means equal I don't know why they had to emphasise it lol"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yeah it becomes more relevant later when you're doing more complex algebra, because if I say x + 3 = 5, that's only true when x is 2. but if I say x + x = 2x, that's ALWAYS true. So I could use an identity sign between them"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh so it just means always?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yeah always equal is a good way to think of it :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Doesn't make any sense to me, but thanks for telling me! One more thing though...."}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're welcome! Yes?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Since you're hear I'd like to check my answers. here*"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Sure!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "So firstly the answer to the question is 4 then the next one is 0 so Liam isn't correct, is that right?"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep great, the order affects the answer there so he's wrong"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Yep. And for Emma, the first question equals  5 then the 2nd one is 6 so she's wrong aswell, is that right? So the answer is D?"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Can you talk me through working out Emma's?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'So for the first question, you would do the multiplication first, 2x1 is 2 then add the 3 is 5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'âœ…'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Then for the 2nd question, 2x1=2 then add the 3 is 5. Wait so actually she's correct"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yeah she is :)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'WAITTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well spotted, sometimes you just need to double check.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'WAITTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'What have you spotted this time?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I put B in the first place and it said it was wrong? Is that a mistake?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Oh! I made a mistake in Liam's! Let's check 3 - 1 + 2"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'YYYYAAAAAASSS. Wait you made this? Cool'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No sorry I meant, just now when I was checking your answer'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Huh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'I got the answer you got BUT I should have done 3 - 1 = 2, then add 2 is ?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "But that's not how you do it. You do addition before subtraction"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ah no, addition and subtraction we do straight across from left to right. They're the same priority level"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Oh just like multiplication and division are the same priority! Makes sense, so it's C? Thanks for helping! :D"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes exactly! It's the one most people forget. You're welcome, glad you spotted that before you went back to the question! Ready to go?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Sorry I was just afk, yes I'd like to go back, thanks1. thanks!*"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem, bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: What is the first square number greater than \( 40 \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 45 \)
Answer B Text: \( 47 \)
Answer C Text: \( 49 \)
Answer D Text: \( 50 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Elizabeth! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi lucia'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you remember what a square number is?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So can you spot one of these options that is a square number?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '47?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Oooh close. But 47 is actually a prime number, it's not in any times tables except 1 and 47... Remember the last square number below 40 would be 36, which is 6 x 6. So which square number comes next?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '49?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's it! Well done ğŸ˜. How do you know 49 is a square number?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont know/'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well 6 x 6 made the last square number, 36, so what can I times together to make 49? __ x ___ = 49'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i know its 7x7 but is there a way to spot any square number'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Nope that is the only way - it is the answer to 7 x 7, so that's what makes it a square number. So if I said for example... 225, you would have to just try multiplying numbers together to see if it's a square number. It's annoying really, which is why it's useful to learn some square numbers off by heart if you canğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok thank you for your help its been a pleasure!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Thank you for your intelligent questions!!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'bye!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Bye Elizabeth, have a good day!'}]

question:
Question Text: Write the following ratio in its simplest form so both sides of the ratio are integers: \( \frac{1}{4}: \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer A Text: \( 4: 2 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2: 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( 2: 1 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1: 2 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Lina!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Any ideas on how to start this one?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'not a clue'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We want to change these fractions into integers, so we need to multiply them to make them both bigger'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How many quarters would we need to make a whole number?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '3. no 4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! 3 more, so times by 4 altogether. question:
Question Text: Write the following ratio in its simplest form so both sides of the ratio are integers: \( \frac{1}{4}: \frac{1}{2} \)
Answer A Text: \( 4: 2 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2: 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( 2: 1 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1: 2 \)

question:
Question Text: Between 2020 and 2021, the population of a city increased by \( 20 \% \)  In 2021, the population of the city was \( 420000 \).  What was the population of the city in 2020?
Answer A Text: \( 504000 \)
Answer B Text: \( 350000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 84000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 336000 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'hello, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont get it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "oh let's start by me asking you how you would usually work out a 20% increase?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'find 1 percent'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "do you know how to do it the quick way using a decimal number we call a multiplier? It's a good method if we are allowed to use a calculator. I can see that you worked out 20% of 420000 and subtracted it but that's not quite the right method for this type of question"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0k'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'are you familiar with 1.20 being the multiplier for a 20% increase? No worries if not'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "that's fine, honestly. Read the question again. so, the 420000 population was the asnwer after the increase. so the population in 2020 was the 100% number in this question. if you have 100% and you add 20% on to it what do you have? 100+20="}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '120'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'yes, so the 2021 population is 120% of the 2020 population. that means that the number in the question, the 420000, represents 120%. and the question is asking us to work out what the 100% was'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is it b'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hi Nathaniel! Celeste's shift has finished so I'm popping in instead. I'll just check for you if it's b - what sum did you do to get that answer?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i estimated'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Well that's a good estimation... So, what Celeste was discussing with you is that because the population had increased by 20%, in 2021, there was now 120%. And we need to calculate what 100% was (the starting population,  in 2020). So we need to do 2021 population Ã· 120 to calculate what 1% is... And then what sum would you do to get 100%?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'iodk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No worries... So first let's do this calculation:. 2021 population Ã· 120 =. 420000 Ã· 120 = 3500. We've done that sum to calculate that 1% of the population = 3500 people. So, then, if I know that 1% = 3500. Then 100% = 1% x 100 = 3500 x 100. Does this make sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, so do you know which answer you'll choose?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes b'}]

Answer C Text: \( 84000 \)

Firstly do you have a calculator to help with this one?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont have a calculator on me but there is an option that says open calculator if thats what you mean?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yep let's use that. Can you tell me what calculation you would normally do to increase something by 20%, using a calculator?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'umm would you find 10% and then *2 and then add that on?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'That would work well without a calculator, but have you learned about decimal multipliers?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no i dont think so'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok, well if we increase something by 20%, what percentage do we have then?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '120%??'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yeah exactly! question:
Question Text: Between 2020 and 2021, the population of a country increased by \( 140 \% \)  In 2021, the population of the country was \( p \).  Which of the following would currently calculate the population of the country in 2020?
Answer A Text: \( p \div 1.4 \)
Answer B Text: \( p \times 0.6 \)
Answer C Text: \( p \times 1.4 \)
Answer D Text: \( p \div 2.4 \)

Answer C Text: \( 146000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 61685 \)

question:
Question Text: Liam buys an investment product for \( Â£ p \) that pays a simple interest rate of \( q \% \) per annum.  Which of the following formulae would calculate the total interest \((I)\) Liam receives after \( n \) years?
Answer A Text: \( I=\left(p \times \frac{q}{100}\right)+n \)
Answer B Text: \( I=\left(p \times \frac{q}{100}\right) \times n \)
Answer C Text: \( I=p \times\left(1+\frac{q}{100}\right)^{n} \)
Answer D Text: \( I=\left( p \times q \right) \times n \)

Interest is money that you either pay or receive when you are borrowing or saving money. For example. I may want to borrow Â£500 from the bank. Question Text: Bea leaves the house at \( 3: 47 \mathrm{pm} \) and is out of the house for \( 5 \) hours and \( 43 \) minutes. At what time does Bea return to the house?
Answer A Text: 9:20pm
Answer B Text: 8:20pm
Answer C Text: 8:30pm
Answer D Text: 9:30pm

Answer C Text: \( 12 \) square units
Answer D Text: \( 16 \) square units

Question Text: What is the area of the triangle?
Question Image: A triangle with each vertex labelled: (7,10), (4,6) and (12,6).
Answer A Text: \( 40 \) square units
Answer B Text: \( 32 \) square units
Answer C Text: \( 12 \) square units
Answer D Text: \( 16 \) square units
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Lina, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im not sure how to work out the answer'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you know how to find the area of a triangle?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes you do base x height divided by 2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's correct. So you're not sure how to work out the lengths of the base and height?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Got you. question:
Question Text: The ratio of \( a: b \) is \( 3: 2 \)  The ratio of \( b: c \) is \( 3: 4 \)  What is the ratio of \( a: c \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 3: 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2: 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( 4: 4 \)
Answer D Text: \( 9: 8 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Liana, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I need help with this question. Pls'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "OK, for this one, you'll want to find a way of writing a ratio of a:b:c. So can you change both ratios so that the B is the same number in both?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I donâ€™t know what to do. I havenâ€™t been taught this'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'At all?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No. Not at all'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Have you been set this by your teacher?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Did you maybe miss a lesson at school?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'No'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Because I see you got most of the questions right.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'It was set by the head of maths. Itâ€™s just this. I havenâ€™t been taught'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'OK, well, we can change what a ratio looks like but keep it worth the same by multiplying both psrts by the same thing. So 3:2 is worth the same as 6:4. or 30:20'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Oh yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'and 3:4 is the same as 6:8 or 30:40 or 9:12'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes. But I still donâ€™t get ir'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "OK, so we've got a:b as 3:2 and b:c as 3:4. We'd like both B numbers to be the same. If we multiply the first ratio by 3, what do we get?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9:6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Correct! And now the B in the first ratio is 6. Can you make the B in the second ratio be 6 as well?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Multiply by 2. 6:8'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Good, now we can combine them to get a:b:c is 9:6:8. Does that make sense to you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes. Thank you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're welcome. Do you think you can see the final answer now? Or would you like me to carry on?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'I think I can do it'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "OK, I'll let you get back to it, well done!"}]

question:
Question Text: What is the equation of this line?
Question Image: A line drawn, on a positive coordinate grid, going through the points (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) (3,3) (4,4)
Answer A Text: \( x=3, y=3 \)
Answer B Text: \( y=x \)
Answer C Text: \( y=-x \)
Answer D Text: \( y=4 x \)

question:
Question Text: Tamsin buys a painting for \( Â£ 80 \) and sells it for \( Â£ 140 \). What percentage profit is this?
Answer A Text: \( 43 \% \)
Answer B Text: \( 60 \% \)
Answer C Text: \( 33 \% \)
Answer D Text: \( 75 \% \)
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi again'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Althea, how can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i just these sorts of questions confusing which is why i need to understand them to help with my test tommorow'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'no problem! to work out percentage profit, you need to use the formula: difference/original x 100. so firstly find the difference between the prices'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Â£60'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'good! and what is the original price?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Â£80'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'good, so you do 60/80 x 100'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '6000/8000. ? hello? Lucille?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'hello sorry I was with another student'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'do 60/80 first'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'what do you mean by that?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '60 divided by 80'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '7.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "almost, it's 0.75"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so...75%/D'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "now multiply that by 100 to turn it into a percentage. good! it's 75% ğŸ˜Š"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so in the future on questions like this I...divide the difference by the original amount and then times that by 100...Correct?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "yes that's exactly it!"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thanks for the help I really appreciate it!ğŸ˜€'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'no problem! have a nice evening'}]

question:
Question Text: This is how Sabrina calculates the answer to \( 13 \times 7 \) mentally First I multiplied \(10 \times 7 = 70\)  Then I multiplied \( 3 \times 7 \), which is \( 21 \) Then I added \( 70 \) and \( 21 \) to get \( 91 \). So \( 13 \times 7=91 \)
Question Text: Sabrina uses the same method to calculate \( 47 \times 3 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{c}4 \times 3=12 \\ 7 \times 3=21 \\ 12+21=33\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{c}40 \times 3=120 \\ 7+3=10 \\ 120+10=130\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{c}40 \times 3=120 \\ 7 \times 3=21 \\ 120+21=230\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( \begin{array}{c}40 \times 3=120 \\ 7 \times 3=21 \\ 120+21=141\end{array} \)

question:
Question Text: This is how Tiffany calculates the answer to \( 13 \times 7 \) mentally First I multiplied \(10 \times 7 = 70\)  Then I multiplied \( 3 \times 7 \), which is \( 21 \) Then I added \( 70 \) and \( 21 \) to get \( 91 \). So \( 13 \times 7=91 \)
Question Text: Tiffany uses the same method to calculate \( 47 \times 3 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{c}4 \times 3=12 \\ 7 \times 3=21 \\ 12+21=33\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{c}40 \times 3=120 \\ 7+3=10 \\ 120+10=130\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{c}40 \times 3=120 \\ 7 \times 3=21 \\ 120+21=230\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( \begin{array}{c}40 \times 3=120 \\ 7 \times 3=21 \\ 120+21=141\end{array} \)

question:

Answer A Text: Multiply by \( 100 \) then subtract the original number
Answer B Text: Multiply by \( 100 \) then add the original number
Answer C Text: Multiply by \( 100 \) then subtract \( 1 \)
Answer D Text: Multiply by \( 100 \) then add \( 1 \)

question:
Question Text: Alex and Sophie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights: \[ 23 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 17 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 40 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 25 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 31 \mathrm{~cm} \]  Alex says if all the plants doubled in height, the range wouldn't change.  Sophie says if all the plants grew by \( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change. Who do you agree with?
Answer A Text: Only Alex
Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Alex and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Question Text: Sam and Lucy are discussing \( 2 x+5 \) where \( x \) is a positive integer Sam says if \( x=5 \) then \( 2 x+5 \) is a multiple of \( 5 \) Lucy says if \( x=2 \) then \( 2 x+5 \) is a multiple of \( 2 \) Who do you agree with?
Answer A Text: Only Sam
Answer B Text: Only Lucy
Answer C Text: Both Sam and Lucy
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Right, first are you confident on what integer and multiple mean?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes integer mean whole number whereas multiple is a number in the designated time table'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Excellent, so we just need to decide whether Sam's calculation gives us a multiple of 5, and whether Lucy's calculation gives a multiple of 2. Starting with Sam, is x = 5 then what is 2x + 5?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '30. or is it 15'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ah I see what you did, yes it's 15 :). 2x means 2 times x. So is that a multiple of 5?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Absolutely! What about Lucy's?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ğŸ˜€'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'If x = 2, what is 2x + 5 this time?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, no problems this time ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ§ . And is that a multiple of 2?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yay! no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Good, nope it is not, so Lucy is not correct this time. Was Sam correct?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ˜Š Great, so there is your answer!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thanks!'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Nice work picking up that algebra so quickly! Bye ğŸ‘‹'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'byee'}]

Question Text: Jack and Emma are discussing the conjecture:  Odd numbers have an odd number of factors  Jack says a counter-example is \( 15 \)  Emma says a counter-example is \( 25 \)  Who do you agree with?
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Answer B Text: Only Sophie
Answer C Text: Both Leo and Sophie
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

question:
Question Text: This table shows the number of pets a group of students owns. To calculate the mean number of pets, Ethan does \( \triangle \div \circ\)  What value should replace \(\triangle\) ?
Question Image: A table with three columns. The first column is headed Number of pets and the rows show 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 with a total of 10 listed in the final row. The middle column is headed Frequency and the rows show 9, 5, 4, 2, 3 with a total of 23 listed in the final row. The last column is headed Number of pets x frequency and the rows show 0, 5, 8, 6, 12 with a total of 31 listed in the final row.
Answer A Text: \( 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( 23 \)
Answer C Text: \( 31 \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Celeste!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Hi luna. I don't really understand how to do this question"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Ok, no problem... So, normally how would you calculate a mean?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I think you add up the total amount and then divide it?? I don't really remember"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great, add up all the pieces of data and then divide by the number of pieces of data (frequency). So, the only difference here is that instead of a list of data, all the data has been arranged in a table. So, can you see in the table that 9 people have 0 pets, 5 people have 1 pet etc......?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yupp'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, so we need to add up all the zeros, ones, twos, threes and fours in the table......as the first step in calculating the mean. So that final column is adding up all the data..... It's done 9x0 because there are 9 zeros.....and then 5x1 because there are 5 ones....etc. Does this make sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes I understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! So, you told me at the start that to calculate the mean we have to add up all the data....that's what the final column is doing... So, what does all the data add up to?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '31?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes!  Well done!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Thank youu'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem!  Are you ready to go back to the lesson?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes I think so. Your a really good teacher'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done! Bye for now ğŸ‘‹. You can call me back if you get stuck.. Thank you! ğŸ˜€'}]

Question Image: A diagram showing the first 3 patterns in a sequence. Pattern 1 is a rectangle with a total of 6 circles surrounding it. Pattern 2 is 2 rectangles with a total of 10 circles surrounding it. Pattern 3 is 3 rectangles with a total of 14 circles surrounding it.
Answer A Text: \( 30 \)
Answer B Text: \( 18 \)
Answer C Text: \( 24 \)
Answer D Text: \( 22 \)
